componenttext: Good morning. My name is Phoenix and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Charter's First Quarter 2016 Investor Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Stefan Anninger, you may begin your conference.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Charter's First Quarter 2016 Investor Call. The presentation that accompanies this call can be found on our website, ir.charter.com, under the Financial Information section. Before we proceed, I would like to remind you that t
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Charter's First Quarter 2016 Investor Call. The presentation that accompanies this call can be found on our website, ir.charter.com, under the Financial Information section. Before we proceed, I would like to remind you that there are a number of risk factors and other cautionary statements contained in our SEC filings, including our most recent proxy statement and forms 10-K and 10-Q. We will not review those risk factors and other cautionary statements on this call, however, we encourage you to read them carefully. Various remarks that we make on this call concerning expectations, predictions, plans and prospects constitute forward-looking statements.  These forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ from historical or anticipated results. Any forward-looking statements reflect management's current view only and Charter undertakes no obligation to revise or update such statements or to make additional forward-looking statements in the future. During the course of today's call, we will be referring to non-GAAP measures as defined and reconciled in our earnings materials. These non-GAAP measures as defined by Charter may not be comparable to measures with similar titles used by other companies. Please also note that all growth rates noted on this call and in the presentation are calculated on a year-over-year basis, unless otherwise specified. 
Joining me on today's call are Tom Rutledge, President and CEO; and Chris Winfrey, our CFO. With that, I'll turn the call over to Tom.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Stefan, and good morning. For some time now, we've been working to combine Charter Time Warner Cable and Bright House, while I'm very pleased with our progress towards closing and integration, I'm just as pleased with Charter's core operating perf
componenttext:
Thanks, Stefan, and good morning. For some time now, we've been working to combine Charter Time Warner Cable and Bright House, while I'm very pleased with our progress towards closing and integration, I'm just as pleased with Charter's core operating performance. Our products, service, customer growth and financial results continue to improve as we deliver more value to our residential and business customers than ever before. Our operating and financial results show the potential growth trajectory that our new operating strategies will drive on a larger set of assets following the close of our transactions and the positive impact that we could have on those communities that will ultimately be served by Charter.
At the end of the first quarter, Charter had 6.8 million residential and SMB customers. Over the last 12 months, we've grown our total customer base by 6% with residential customer growth of 5% and small business customer growth of 18%. We continue to grow our video customer base in the first quarter. Total video customers grew by 15,000, including 10,000 residential video net adds and our all-digital video product enables HD and on-demand on every outlet. And we fully deployed our TBF for both mobile devices and media players for content delivery, both in and out of home. 
We recently launched our cloud-based EUI in St. Louis, in addition to Reno. It continues to scale well and is resonating with consumers. 
We also continue to grow our Internet business. Residential Internet customers grew by 9% over the last 12 months. During the first quarter, we added 141,000 Residential Internet customers. The strong demand that we're seeing for our Internet service is being driven by offering minimum 60 megabits speeds, quality service and consumer-friendly features, including unlimited data usage and no modem fees. 
Including voice, we added 186,000 PSUs in the first quarter, over 20% more than the 154,000 we added in the first quarter of 2015. 
We also continue to see improving commercial customer net additions with SMB PSU growth accelerating by 68% year-over-year in the first quarter. That customer growth improvement is being driven by the launch of new small business pricing and packaging in the first quarter of last year. 
We also launched new pricing and packaging for enterprise in the fourth quarter, including a deeper gigabit service offering that's driving a significant increase in sales. During the quarter, we grew our total revenue by 7.1% with even less reliance on rate increases. 
Our first quarter adjusted EBITDA grew by over 10% year-over-year whether you include transition expenses or not. So EBITDA growth continues to exceed our revenue growth as it has for several quarters now as we take operating transactions out of the business through investing in our network, systems and people. 
We have a fully integrated operating strategy and business model, which is based on a clear centralized organizational structure, creating a superior product set package of highly competitive prices to sell more product. Unleashing the full capacity of our 2-way interactive network by going all-digital, insourcing service operations, people, cloud-based services and product platforms and continuous product development to stay ahead. As a result, the high level of growth that Charter can be sustainable for a long period of time. 
It's also an indication of what we believe we can do at Time Warner Cable and Bright House, that will require time and investments just as it did at Charter but I believe it can happen faster because of the relatively better starting condition of the assets we're acquiring. And we'll also benefit from transaction synergies to help offset the investments to achieve those operating synergies. I also believe our approach and track record here at Charter over the last several years will make the trends at new Charter easier for investors to understand over the next several years. 
So our customer growth and financial performance is very good as we had planned. Our sales are up and our residential churn is down. And in the first quarter, we saw 15% year-over-year reduction in billing and service calls as well as a 19% reduction in service truck roll volume. Our field service truck rolls are now 80% insources versus 50% in 2012 and it's increasing. And call center activity is now 90% insourced. In total, since the beginning of 2012, we've increased our workforce by over 7,000 people with the vast majority of the increase driven by insourcing. 
With our all-digital transition complete and secure 2-way boxes installed on every residential outlet, in April, we began to perform electronic disconnects instead of physical truck rolls. This change in practice also allows us to fully scale our self-install practices beyond what we did during all-digital. Electronic disconnects and self-installs will provide significant benefits to Charter systems in the coming years. It will also reduce operating cost and capital expenditures and raise customer satisfaction through greater control over the installation process and will also reduce the opportunity for self-service failure in a way that provide even better security.
Turning to the closing process with TWC and Bright House. On April 12, the administrative law judge, signed by the California PUC, reviewed our transactions recommended that our transactions be approved by the California Public Utilities Commission. We expect the PUC to vote on the judge's recommendation on May 12, all of our states have approved our transactions.
We're also pleased that the FCC Chairman has circulated an order approving our transactions and that the DOJ has filed a proposed judgment with the District Court under which our proposed transactions may precede. Assuming we receive FCC approval, we will expect to officially close our transactions within just a few days of receiving approval from the California PUC.
Next several months and quarters will be an exciting time for New Charter and after a lot of creative thought, we decided to call the new company, Charter. Our first priority is to get our people in the right roles and reporting structures with the right responsibilities. We've already announced Charter's organizational structure and leadership across the 3 organizations. 
Our corporate organization as well as marketing, sales and product development departments will be centralized over a period of 6 months following close. Our field operations group, which is the largest organization will be managed through 11 different regional areas. Each of those regions has been designed to represent a logical combination of designated marketing areas and these regions will be managed largely the same set of field employees with the 3 companies today. 
Following close, customer care will continue to be operated as a currently is in each of the 3 companies today. Over time, customer care will migrate to the Charter model of using virtualized you U.S.-based in-house call centers. This migration process is likely to take several years as it has here at Charter. 
A partial driver of the timing of our customer care transition is the pace of its IT and network operations integrations progress. Our goals with these integrations will be to minimize a service disruptions and to enable the business to deploy superior products and services.
Managing the all-digital transition at Time Warner Cable and Bright House will also be a key priority. At close, we will briefly paused any new digital rollouts at both companies and then restart them deploying fully enabled two-way set-top boxes everywhere and discontinuing DA deployments. Concurrent with all-digital, we'll introduce new product and pricing and packaging. We'll also launch our new pricing and packaging across those portions of TWC and BHN footprints that have already gone all-digital. We plan to complete all-digital and the launch of new pricing and packaging across all 36 million passings that TWC and Bright House by the end of 2018. 
In the historic Charter markets, we expect to make our cloud-based user available in most markets by the end of 2016. We're still working through our guide rollout plans for TWC and Bright House markets, that includes a coordinating guide rollouts with our market-by-market plans for all-digital and relaunch of new pricing and packaging. Ultimately, our goal is to offer our customers the significant guide to benefit as quickly as possible, if not at the cost of disruption to service operations of the customer. So we'll have more to report once we actually close and start running the businesses.
Our plans are in place and we're ready to go to work and we remain confident as ever about the benefits that our transaction will bring to our customers employees and our shareholders. I'd like to thank Charter's employees for their hard work and dedication to getting us where we are so far and to our financial stakeholders who continues to support us. 
Now I'll hand the call over to Chris to take you through the financials.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. Starting with Slide 7 of today's presentation. During the first quarter, we grew residential PSUs by 186,000 versus 154,000 last year. And in video, we added 10,000 residential customers versus a loss of 13,000 last year. In Residential Inter
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. Starting with Slide 7 of today's presentation. During the first quarter, we grew residential PSUs by 186,000 versus 154,000 last year. And in video, we added 10,000 residential customers versus a loss of 13,000 last year. In Residential Internet, we added 141,000 customers versus 125,000 last year and we grew residential voice customers by 35,000 versus 42,000 last year. 
Over the last year, our essential customer base has grown by 318,000, or by 5%. And over the same period, residential ARPU was up by 1.4%, driven by a larger triple-play base and step-ups and modest rate adjustments, partially offset by continued single play Internet growth. 
As Slide 9 shows, our customer growth, combined with our ARPU growth, resulted in year-over-year residential revenue growth of 6.5%. That compares to 6.7% last year as our faster customer growth offsets lower rate increases as designed. 
In commercial, we added 32,000 SMB PSUs versus 19,000 in the prior year, that improvement follows the separation of our SMB and enterprise groups with new SMB pricing and packaging launched late last year. Total commercial revenue grew by approximately 12% and continues reflect the same short-term ARPU pressure we saw in residential when we initially launched our new pricing and packaging in 2012.
Our advertising revenue was up about 9% year-over-year driven by a $5 million increase in political. 
In total, the first quarter revenue was up by 7.1% year-over-year and the same excluding advertising. 
Turning to first quarter operating expenses and adjusted EBITDA on Slide 10. Total operating expense grew by $85 million or 5.4% year-over-year, the transition OpEx accounting for $21 million of our total OpEx this quarter.
Programming expense grew by $37 million accounting for just under half of the year-over-year increase in total operating expense. The 5.5% increase in first quarter programming was driven by contractual rate increases, growth in our video customer base over the last year, higher penetration of our tiers and the launch of new channels, including the Dodgers. Excluding the onetime expense benefit and the growth in our video customer base year-over-year, programming expense would have grown by 6%, flat, versus the prior year quarter.
Cost of service customers, which includes field operations, customer care, network operating costs declined slightly year-over-year, despite residential and SMB customer relationship growth of 5.9%, that ties directly to the operating metrics Tom highlighted and both consistent and improving relative to what we've seen for several quarters. 
Other costs grew by $34 million, or about 18% year-over-year, driven by some additional corporate and administrative labor expense, including the insourcing of IT and software development resources and advertising and enterprise costs. Property taxes in previous CapEx and higher casualty claims due to more insourced employee base. Excluding a onetime nonrecurring expenses, this other expense category would have grown by 13% year-over-year. 
First quarter adjusted EBITDA improved by over 10% year-over-year whether you include transition cost or not, and continue to exceed our revenue. As Tom mentioned, the continued growth of revenue capacity and operating improvement is in its early stage for Charter systems and has momentum. 
Moving to Slide 12. First quarter capital expenditures totaled $429 million or $53 million related to M&A transactions spend. That spending begin with the Comcast transaction and has provided us a head start to providing a uniform product and service package to TWC and Bright House customers beginning postclose. Excluding transition CapEx in both periods, our first quarter CapEx was up by just over $39 million, or 12%, driven primarily by our investments in product development and the end-year timing of the fleet purchases, which falls into the support capital line. For 2016, excluding the impact of transition CapEx and the pending acquisitions, we expect our CapEx as a percentage of revenue to continue to decline at Charter year-over-year.
First quarter free cash flow was a negative $61 million and the year-over-year decline was primarily driven by the higher cash interest on our transaction-related debt and escrow. And from higher CapEx for the reasons I just outlined.
If you exclude the impact of our transaction, specifically, $21 million of our operating expense, $53 million of CapEx, $259 million of cash interest and escrow and $14 million of transaction costs and other expenses, our free cash flow, adjusted for the transaction spend, totaled approximately $280 million, that's up significantly versus last year on the same basis.
As of March 31, our net debt to LTM EBITDA was 4.1x. The $21.8 billion of cash sitting in escrow for our transactions, plus term loan a commitments and combined liquidity at close, flee finances our transaction assuming TWC shareholders elect $100 cash option. At closing, we still expect to be levered at 4.5x or less on an LTM basis and assuming the first 12 months run rate synergies of approximately $500 million.
In February, we issued $1.7 billion of senior unsecured notes and in April, we issued an additional $1.5 billion of senior unsecured notes. We intend to use the proceeds from these offerings to redeem Charter's currently callable outstanding higher price debt, although part of the proceeds from the February offer could be used to finance our transactions TWC shareholders were to elect to receive $115 per share in cash rather than $100.
Turning to the pending transactions. We expect the second quarter will be the first quarter for which we will report our results following close and I wanted to give you a brief preview on how we expect to report as mention a few things to better navigate our second quarter results. With an anticipated mid-quarter closing, our second quarter results will reflect a full quarter from legacy Charter, plus subpeers for TWC and Bright House, so year-over-year actual comparisons won't really be helpful but we will provide historical pro formas for the 3 companies under the historical management. We intend to present Charter's quarterly trending schedule with a pro forma data, along the lines of what do you received today, dating back to the beginning of 2014. Moving forward, we'll report similar customer, PSU and revenue data for Charter's 3 legacy entities for at least 5 quarters following close, both separately and, of course, under consolidated basis. This approach is going to allow you to track the development of each of the 3 legacy entities. 
We'll not show expenses or capital expenditures by legacy entity. It's not really practical given the shared nature of large key items like programming, overhead and significant centralized capital spend.
We'll also continue to report a transition expense and capital related to the integration and we'll provide updates in conference calls on certain items, including estimates for the synergies we've realia zed, so you can better isolated the organic growth of the business. We'll probably do that for about 2 years, beginning in the first full quarter of results. 
Our balance sheet and P&L will also be materially impacted by purchase price accounting and allocation. And part of that will be a significant fair market value a step-up of TWC and Bright House assets, reflecting the fair market value consideration we provide as of the closing dates. The step ups will primarily be in PNG, franchises, customer relationships and goodwill. I've heard none of the 3 companies assets will be step-up of our tax purposes. As a result of the difference between the stepped-up GAAP basis and the existing tax basis at TWC, there will be a significant increase to our deferred tax liability on our GAAP balance sheet. On a pro forma basis, it is already reflected in our S-4 and other filings, the GAAP basis step-up will also increase Charter's GAAP DNA charges above what the simple additional of historical DNA would be for the 3 legacy entities. 
Purchase price accounting will also likely result in the posting of an opening liability on the balance sheet to reflect an estimates of the outer market portion of TWC's distribution agreement with the Dodgers. They'll be no change of the TWC cash payments as a result of that accounting about the future P&L expense would be lower as a result.
We'll also modify the value at TWC's legacy do to it's a fair market value at closing. And the difference between the fair value at closing and the actual principal amount will amortize over the remaining term of each tranche of debt, driving a difference between GAAP and cash interest expense. 
So those are some of the largest key items that will result from purchase accounting and there are a number of other key post closing items that are mentioned that will impact the consolidated financials. Our share count, which stands at approximately 112 million shares outstanding today will increase at close as we issues shares to TWC shareholders and to Liberty broadband. Given that Advance/Newhouse [indiscernible] anytime, it make sense for investors to include those partnership units on an as-exchange basis when evaluating Charter's total equity value and any Charter share-based metrics.
Also keep in mind that as part of the transaction, Charter will undergo what we refer to and explain more detail in our S-4 as the parent merger exchange. This transaction will essentially haircut the number of shares outstanding for the entire company for all shareholders, including Advance/Newhouse partnership unit by approximately 10%. 
The parent Merger exchange will be value neutral to all parties aggregate holdings in Charter but it will reduce the overall share counts of the company both on the shares outstanding basis and on an as-exchange basis, again, by about 10%.
In theory, new Charter's stock market price should reflect this reduction in shares with commensurate share price increase the New Charter stop against the trade on the NASDAQ. Slide 22 in the appendix of today's investor presentation should provide investors with a better understanding of Charter's share count and how the shares outstanding change for the parent merger exchange and the Advance/Newhouse unit on an as-exchange basis.
Moving on to some more post closing accounting and reporting housekeeping. At close, TWC employees who currently hold TWC stock awards will see no stock awards replace with New Charter stock awards which will mirror their current economics. The post closing vesting of these awards will increase stock compensation expense postclosing to reflect the updated fair value of these replacement stock awards as compared to their original brand value. We should also mention after closing substantially all of the $3 billion valuation allowance, which is posted against legacy Charter's deferred tax assets, is expected to be removed as the use of our NOLs will now be accelerated in Charter's consolidated tax return. 
The legacy Charter deferred tax asset account on the balance sheet today and net income in that quarter will both increased by approximately $3 billion as a onetime benefit. We'll also expense a quarterly charge of approximately $38 million in preferred coupon for Advance/Newhouse ownership of the preferred partnership units. That charge will be reported on separate line as noncontrolling interest expense.
We'll also have some transaction adviser expenses for both Charter and TWC, which are contingent closing already disclosed in the S-4 as well as commitments for our financing. And we expect below the line for structuring and termination expenses through the integration process that will post below the EBITDA line as well.
Finally, turning to our tax assets, as we indicated on our last call, we don't expect Charter to be a significant cash tax payer until 2018. And even then, our cash taxes as a percentage of GAAP pretax income should be below statutory rates for several years thereafter. And when I refer to GAAP pretax income, we are excluding the impact of the pending purchase price accounting that we'll have on GAAP depreciation add more text expense going forward.
We do expect the transactions to trigger a change of ownership under Section 382 of the tax code. And while that change in ownership will again restrict the pace which NOLs will become available, we don't expect it to negatively impact the net present value of our tax assets at the last time as the transactions here will create a larger base of taxable income, ultimately accelerating the utilization of our NOLs versus stand-alone Charter today. 
Operator, with that, we're ready for questions now.

componenttextpreview: Well, it'll take some time to roll out new pricing and packaging across Time Warner and Bright House. The plan is to, as I described, to continue the all-digital project that is going on currently at Time Warner and to initiate a similar project at Bright
componenttext: Well, it'll take some time to roll out new pricing and packaging across Time Warner and Bright House. The plan is to, as I described, to continue the all-digital project that is going on currently at Time Warner and to initiate a similar project at Bright House in the Tampa area and as we do that to roll out new pricing and packaging behind it. We also intend to launch within a matter of 4 months or so new pricing and packaging against the parts of the company that has already gone all-digital. And to get it rolled out over the period of time it takes to do all-digital, which could take through the end of '18.

componenttext: And through that period, do you expect any meaningful change into the Time Warner Cable just posted a pretty solid top line growth number, do you expect any impact on the growth rates of those assets?

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, yes. We're going to have to integrate those assets into our packaging and pricing and we're going to have costs associated with that. And we -- our objective is to actually accelerate the growth rate. And in order to do that, we're going to spend
componenttext: I think, yes. We're going to have to integrate those assets into our packaging and pricing and we're going to have costs associated with that. And we -- our objective is to actually accelerate the growth rate. And in order to do that, we're going to spend more capital by going all-digital and putting 2-way interactive boxes on every outlet. And we're going to package in such a way that we think we get longer-term revenue growth and get that revenue growth over a longer period of time with the quality of the products that we're selling into the markets. So they've done very well, which we're very pleased with. The assets are in better shape than we even planned for, which is a great relief. But we did we do have plans to spend money and spend capital in order to have a uniform product that we think create a longer-term growth prospects that will produce consistent long-term growth rates.

componenttext: So let me start with the second one. No, that's not the right interpretation, although I'm glad that you as it because it should highlight for people. I was giving a commitment that we'll report that amount on a going backwards basis of how much is realized inside the quarter for 2 years. It could end up being longer depending on where we're actually at. I think when we said in the past is that we expect synergies to be over the course of 3 years to be fully baked into the actuals and there wasn't a change of I think I could be. So after 2 years, we've evaluate where we are, but give people clarity on how current reports the business in the upcoming 2 years at a minimum. On the active video JV that we have with Arris, it's a productive relationship that we have, both with the management team and ActiveVideo as well as Arris who runs 65%. We have a couple of board seat in that investment. We're treated as an independent third-party vendor inside of the relationship with ActiveVideo. So I guess, the benefit would be the ability to see what the pipeline of product that they have coming in the future and to have oversight in terms of how that's being developed elsewhere. But we saw an attractive product that we were using amongst other vendors in our Spectrum Guide platform and we thought it was an interesting equity investment, but also a strategic importance to Charter.

componenttext: And to further answer your question, that ActiveVideo technology platform allows us to use existing set-top boxes and put state-of-the-art user interface on already those departments is an attempt to replace those boxes, so that they essentially become state-of-the-art boxes. And that's the capital advantage of having that vendor relationships.

componenttext: A couple, please. First on synergies now that the deal is pretty much done, we've always thought that $800 million was kind of conservative. Is there a new view on that? And is it fair to sort of assume that programming step downs on the Charter base will happen pretty much immediately on the deal closing? And then just on the all-digital plan, I think -- I've estimated that there's about 13 million, 14 million DTAs in out to boxes within the Time Warner Cable and Bright House. Is that a sort of the right base that we could see being transitioned to all-digital?

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe I get this first 2, we can tag team  this [indiscernible]. On the $800 million, I think there was a general misconception right from the get-go is what we call synergies. The $800 million was a 3-year run rate of transaction synergies. What we don't
componenttext: Maybe I get this first 2, we can tag team  this [indiscernible]. On the $800 million, I think there was a general misconception right from the get-go is what we call synergies. The $800 million was a 3-year run rate of transaction synergies. What we don't include in that is the operating synergies that come from taking a different philosophy towards pricing and packaging and insourcing service and lowering the amount of transactions. So the transaction synergies, we're not giving an update on our thoughts around that other than we think there was other than anticipate we always thought it was conservative, we still do. But that's really tied to the elimination of duplicative overhead programming and other transaction-related synergies of just putting the companies together, it's not a change in the operating strategies which is how you get additional profitability capacity over time. So one can argue and say well, to the synergies are obviously much, much higher than the $800 million, and I would agree with that but that's really a chance of the way that of the businesses are operating as opposed to M&A transaction synergies, which is what the $800 million refers to. On programming timing, yes, we believe we'll step into the Time Warner Cable [indiscernible] in the appropriate places effectively at close. And on DTAs, I don't have...

componenttext: I'm not sure that, that I can't verify that your number is correct off the top of my head. So as we transect business and move people into new pricing and packaging, we'll get the new customer base on the new pricing platform, a two-way boxes on every outlet, so they'll be [indiscernible] in some of these markets for years to come.

componenttext: Tom, I don't know if you do want to shed some light for us on the SEC's approach around the set-top box, NPRM and also the special access noise that's been going on lately given how much time you spent in D.C. over the last few months and year, if you could just tell us how you think those 2 may or may not impact the new company going forward? headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Ben, you're right, I spent a lot of time there, but focused on other things. The -- we -- from Charter's point of view, we don't charge for modems and we try to keep our box prices low relatively speaking and we have made our applications available
componenttext: Well, Ben, you're right, I spent a lot of time there, but focused on other things. The -- we -- from Charter's point of view, we don't charge for modems and we try to keep our box prices low relatively speaking and we have made our applications available on other set-top boxes that consumers could purchase. And so from a -- if you just look at that as people being concerned about the price of boxes, we think that our operating practice is fit with that goal. The control of copyright and the control of privacy are real issues and we have a strong views that they should be protected. With regard to special access, we haven't seen the full scope of that yet, only what's been publicized. And we're a nascent player in that market with the whole cable industry, I think, is less than 10% penetrated against that very large marketplace. And so it seems premature to me to be thinking about regulating a new entrant to a marketplace.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Cost of service, no, there's not any onetime benefit that's sitting inside the number, that's real operating leverage, if you want to use that term. It is directly a result of lower service calls to the and a significantly lower service truck roll truck r
componenttext: Cost of service, no, there's not any onetime benefit that's sitting inside the number, that's real operating leverage, if you want to use that term. It is directly a result of lower service calls to the and a significantly lower service truck roll truck rolls out in the field. And so what that means is that your ability to have a larger number of customers with a higher amount of revenue and lower underlying operating cost because you have fewer calls and truck rolls taking place. That continues to improve at Charter. And we've just made some additional changes that Tom mentioned in terms of stopping to do hard disconnects now that we have the plant secured...

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: The hard disconnects means that a truck trip to a telephone pole and then a reconnect on every transaction. So it's really your churn rate times to transactions.

componenttextpreview: So it's a significant reduction in costs going forward.
componenttext: So it's a significant reduction in costs going forward.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, but I think the operating cost strategy that we have is something that we've been working on for a long time, and I'm very proud that it's actually showing up now before we get a lot of confusing numbers going forward. We have been working on a prici
componenttext: Yes, but I think the operating cost strategy that we have is something that we've been working on for a long time, and I'm very proud that it's actually showing up now before we get a lot of confusing numbers going forward. We have been working on a pricing and packaging strategy that reduces activity all through the marketing process and the activation process of customers. It's designed to increase the life of subscriptions, so for the same dollars of revenue with longer customer life being less churn, same dollars of revenue, you have less cost per customer because you have less physical activity per dollar of revenue. And by maintaining our plant properly and by improving the quality of our craftsmanship by our employee base, which we've been hiring and training, we reduce service calls and that that further improves customer satisfaction, which improves subscriber life. And all of those things are taking transaction costs out of the business, even though our labor costs on a per transaction basis are going up, our transaction reductions are exceeding that rate of increase in the cost per transaction and overall cost of running the business are going down, and that's a very virtuous cycle.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes, so 5% customer growth with flat cost service is actually you guys sound like you can sustain for a bit not in those numbers but at least directionally.

componenttext: I think what we're trying to do is to avoid giving a guidance because typically we don't. And we think we can grow and structure between TWC and Bright House and Charter, we shouldn't be that much difference in terms of where penetration can get to [indiscernible] 3 sets of assets. On ARPU there are structural differences between Time Warner Cable, Bright House and Charter and that's really a function of how they come to market. The biggest one is just the amount of single, double and triple-play. And we and TWC both disclosed the numbers there. They've been going to market over the past year, 1.5 years with similar triple-play but we still very different a box or equipment pricing model and that's one of the areas that we're going to work through new pricing and packaging to put that into the Charter format so that you can have longer-term growth with lower amount of equipment rental and in some cases, no equipment rental and in modem fees and thus make a difference and a pretty similar to Time Warner Cable and Bright House. So there are structural differences in the our goal would be to make sure that as we go through new pricing and packaging that we actually don't hurt revenue along the way that continue to grow with [indiscernible] subscriber volume and customer relationship volume as well as additional PSUs per households.

componenttext: Right. Well, the DOJ's consent to [indiscernible] actually public. And they made comments in their releases stating that there wasn't anything in our particular practices that was concern of theirs but there's more things they discovered in some of the Time Warner agreements. So our go-to-market strategy and our programming relationships are designed to encourage the sale of our existing products and the development of over-the-top products. Our broadband package and the capabilities of our broadband service are realized when customers use it. And they use it when they subscribe to over-the-top services, videos, most bandwidth intensive product there is. Also we have a superior now work, which we've invested to make superior, we've cleared it to create more Spectrum available for broadband, we've taken broadband speeds up and capabilities up. And the way that are drive into the marketplace is accelerated is by peoples perceiving the value of our broadband and the way the perceived that value is through over-the-top. So we can hold all these concert in our head of the same time in go-to-market, and we do. And we do think that the market is evolving and the price of value of products are evolving. And we look to take advantage of that where we can using our scale and using our strategy with programmers and our relationships with programmers to be as efficient as possible.

componenttext: Yes. So the way to think about it isn't really to think about ARPU but to think about the growth rate, which we said an accelerated 68% year-over-year. It's really a revamp of our strategy to go to a more fast-growing market share strategy in SMB just like we do in residential.

Good morning. My name is Phoenix, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Charter's First Quarter 2016 Investor Call. [Operator Instructions]
I would now like to turn the call over to Stefan Anninger, you may begin your conference.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Charter's First Quarter 2016 Investor Call. The presentation that accompanies this call can be found on our website, ir.charter.com, under the Financial Information section. Before we proceed, I would like to remind you that
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Charter's First Quarter 2016 Investor Call. The presentation that accompanies this call can be found on our website, ir.charter.com, under the Financial Information section. 
Before we proceed, I would like to remind you that there are a number of risk factors and other cautionary statements contained in our SEC filings, including our most recent proxy statement and forms 10-K and 10-Q. We will not review those risk factors and other cautionary statements on this call, however, we encourage you to read them carefully. Various remarks that we make on this call concerning expectations, predictions, plans and prospects constitute forward-looking statements.  
These forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ from historical or anticipated results. Any forward-looking statements reflect management's current view only and Charter undertakes no obligation to revise or update such statements or to make additional forward-looking statements in the future. 
During the course of today's call, we will be referring to non-GAAP measures as defined and reconciled in our earnings materials. These non-GAAP measures as defined by Charter may not be comparable to measures with similar titles used by other companies. Please also note that all growth rates noted on this call and in the presentation are calculated on a year-over-year basis, unless otherwise specified. 
Joining me on today's call are Tom Rutledge, President and CEO; and Chris Winfrey, our CFO. With that, I'll turn the call over to Tom.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Stefan, and good morning. For some time now, we've been working to combine Charter, Time Warner Cable and Bright House. While I'm very pleased with our progress towards closing and integration, I'm just as pleased with Charter's core operating per
componenttext:
Thanks, Stefan, and good morning. For some time now, we've been working to combine Charter, Time Warner Cable and Bright House. While I'm very pleased with our progress towards closing and integration, I'm just as pleased with Charter's core operating performance. Our products, service, customer growth and financial results continue to improve as we deliver more value to our residential and business customers than ever before. Our operating and financial results show the potential growth trajectory that our new operating strategies will drive on a larger set of assets following the close of our transactions and the positive impact that we can have on those communities that will ultimately be served by Charter.
At the end of the first quarter, Charter had 6.8 million residential and SMB customers. Over the last 12 months, we've grown our total customer base by 6% with residential customer growth of 5% and small business customer growth of 18%. We continue to grow our video customer base in the first quarter. Total video customers grew by 15,000, including 10,000 residential video net adds and our all-digital video product enables HD and on-demand on every outlet. And we fully deployed our TBF for both mobile devices and media players for content delivery, both in and out of home. 
We recently launched our cloud-based EUI in St. Louis, in addition to Reno. It continues to scale well and is resonating with consumers. 
We also continue to grow our Internet business. Residential Internet customers grew by 9% over the last 12 months. During the first quarter, we added 141,000 Residential Internet customers. The strong demand that we're seeing for our Internet service is being driven by offering minimum 60 megabits speeds, quality service and consumer-friendly features, including unlimited data usage and no modem fees. 
Including voice, we added 186,000 PSUs in the first quarter, over 20% more than the 154,000 we added in the first quarter of 2015. 
We also continue to see improving commercial customer net additions, with SMB PSU growth accelerating by 68% year-over-year in the first quarter. That customer growth improvement is being driven by the launch of new small business pricing and packaging in the first quarter of last year. 
We also launched new pricing and packaging for enterprise in the fourth quarter, including a deeper gigabit service offering that's driving a significant increase in sales. During the quarter, we grew our total revenue by 7.1% with even less reliance on rate increases. 
Our first quarter adjusted EBITDA grew by over 10% year-over-year whether you include transition expenses or not. So EBITDA growth continues to exceed our revenue growth as it has for several quarters now as we take operating transactions out of the business through investing in our network, systems and people. 
We have a fully integrated operating strategy and business model, which is based on a clear centralized organizational structure, creating a superior product set packaged at highly competitive prices to sell more product. Unleashing the full capacity of our 2-way interactive network by going all-digital, insourcing service operations, people, cloud-based services and product platforms and continuous product development to stay ahead. As a result, the higher level of growth that Charter can be sustainable for a long period of time. 
It's also an indication of what we believe we can do at Time Warner Cable and Bright House, that will require time and investment just as it did at Charter, but I believe it can happen faster because of the relatively better starting condition of the assets we're acquiring. And we'll also benefit from transaction synergies to help offset the investments to achieve those operating synergies. I also believe our approach and track record here at Charter over the last several years will make the trends at new Charter easier for investors to understand over the next several years. 
So our customer growth and financial performance is very good as we had planned. Our sales are up and our residential churn is down. And in the first quarter, we saw 15% year-over-year reduction in billing and service calls as well as a 19% reduction in service truck roll volume. Our field service truck rolls are now 80% insources versus 50% in 2012 and it's increasing. And call center activity is now 90% insourced. In total, since the beginning of 2012, we've increased our workforce by over 7,000 people, with the vast majority of the increase driven by insourcing. 
With our all-digital transition complete and secure 2-way boxes installed on every residential outlet, in April, we began to perform electronic disconnects instead of physical truck rolls. This change in practice also allows us to fully scale our self-install practices beyond what we did during all-digital. Electronic disconnects and self-installs will provide significant benefits to Charter systems in the coming years. It will also reduce operating cost and capital expenditures and raise customer satisfaction through greater control over the installation process and we'll also reduce the opportunity for self-service failure in a way that provide even better security.
Turning to the closing process with TWC and Bright House. On April 12, the administrative law judge, assigned by the California PUC to review our transactions recommended that our transactions be approved by the California Public Utility Commission. We expect the CPUC to vote on the judge's recommendation on May 12, all of our states have approved our transactions.
We're also pleased that the FCC Chairman has circulated an order approving our transactions and that the DOJ has filed a proposed judgment with the District Court under which our proposed transactions may precede. Assuming we receive FCC approval, we will expect to officially close our transactions within just a few days of receiving approval from the California PUC.
Next several months and quarters will be an exciting time for New Charter and after a lot of creative thought, we decided to call the new company, Charter. Our first priority is to get our people in the right roles and reporting structures with the right responsibilities. We've already announced Charter's organizational structure and leadership across the 3 organizations. 
Our corporate organization as well as marketing, sales and product development departments will be centralized over a period of 6 months following close. Our field operations group, which is the largest organization will be managed through 11 different regional areas. Each of those regions has been designed to represent a logical combination of designated marketing areas and these regions will be managed largely the same set of field employees that are with the 3 companies today. 
Following close, customer care will continue to be operated as it currently is in each of the 3 companies today. Over time, customer care will migrate to the Charter model of using virtualized U.S.-based, in-house call centers. This migration process is likely to take several years as it has here at Charter. 
A partial driver of the timing of our customer care transition is the pace at which our IT and network operations integrations progress. Our goals with these integrations will be to minimize service disruptions and to enable the business to deploy superior products and services.
Managing the all-digital transition at Time Warner Cable and Bright House will also be a key priority. At close, we will briefly pause any new digital rollouts at both companies and then restart them deploying fully enabled two-way set-top boxes everywhere and discontinuing D to A deployments. Concurrent with all-digital, we'll introduce new product and pricing and packaging. We'll also launch our new pricing and packaging across those portions of TWC and BHN footprints that have already gone all-digital. We plan to complete all-digital and the launch of new pricing and packaging across all 36 million passings that TWC and Bright House by the end of 2018. 
In the historic Charter markets, we expect to make our cloud-based user interface available in most markets by the end of 2016. We're still working through our guide rollout plans for TWC and Bright House markets, that includes a coordinating guide rollouts with our market-by-market plans for all-digital and relaunch of new pricing and packaging. Ultimately, our goal is to offer our customers the significant guide benefit as quickly as possible, if not at the cost of disruption to service operations of the customer. So I'll have more to report on once we actually close and start running the businesses.
Our plans are in place and we're ready to go to work, and we remain confident as ever about the benefits that our transaction will bring to our customers, employees and our shareholders. I'd like to thank Charter's employees for their hard work and dedication to getting us where we are so far and to our financial stakeholders who have continued to support us. 
Now I'll hand the call over to Chris to take you through the financials.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. Starting with Slide 7 of today's presentation. During the first quarter, we grew residential PSUs by 186,000 versus 154,000 last year. And in video, we added 10,000 residential customers versus a loss of 13,000 last year. In Residential Inter
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. Starting with Slide 7 of today's presentation. During the first quarter, we grew residential PSUs by 186,000 versus 154,000 last year. And in video, we added 10,000 residential customers versus a loss of 13,000 last year. In Residential Internet, we added 141,000 customers versus 125,000 last year and we grew residential voice customers by 35,000 versus 42,000 last year. 
Over the last year, our residential customer base has grown by 318,000, or by 5%. And over the same period, residential ARPU was up by 1.4%, driven by a larger triple-play base and step-ups and modest rate adjustments, partially offset by continued single play Internet growth. 
As Slide 9 shows, our customer growth, combined with our ARPU growth, resulted in year-over-year residential revenue growth of 6.5%. That compares to 6.7% last year as our faster customer growth offsets lower rate increases as designed.
In commercial, we added 32,000 SMB PSUs versus 19,000 in the prior year, that improvement follows the separation of our SMB and enterprise groups, with new SMB pricing and packaging launched late last year. Total commercial revenue grew by approximately 12% and continues to reflect the same short-term ARPU pressure we saw in residential, when we initially launched our new pricing and packaging in 2012.
Our advertising revenue was up about 9% year-over-year driven by a $5 million increase in political. In total, the first quarter revenue was up by 7.1% year-over-year and the same when excluding advertising. 
Turning to first quarter operating expenses and adjusted EBITDA on Slide 10. Total operating expense grew by $85 million or 5.4% year-over-year, the transition OpEx accounting for $21 million of our total OpEx this quarter.
Programming expense grew by $37 million accounting for just under half of the year-over-year increase in total operating expense. The 5.5% increase in first quarter programming was driven by contractual rate increases, growth in our video customer base over the last year, higher penetration of our tiers and the launch of new channels, including the Dodgers. Excluding the onetime expense benefit and the growth in our video customer base year-over-year, programming expense would have grown by 6% flat versus the prior year quarter.
Cost of service customers, which includes field operations, customer care, network operating cost declined slightly year-over-year, despite residential and SMB customer relationship growth of 5.9%, that ties directly to the operating metrics Tom highlighted and is both consistent and improving relative to what we've seen for several quarters. 
Other costs grew by $34 million, or about 18% year-over-year, driven by some additional corporate and administrative labor expense, including the insourcing of IT and software development resources and advertising and enterprise cost. Property taxes on previous CapEx and the higher casualty claims due to a more insourced employee base. Excluding a onetime nonrecurring expense, this other expense category would have grown by 13% year-over-year. 
First quarter adjusted EBITDA grew by over 10% year-over-year, whether you include transition cost or not, and continued to exceed our revenue growth. As Tom mentioned, the continued growth of revenue per capacity and operating improvement is at an early stage for Charter systems and has momentum. 
Moving to Slide 12. First quarter capital expenditures totaled $429 million or $53 million related to M&A transaction spend. That spending began with the Comcast transactions and has provided us a head start to providing a uniform product and service package to TWC and Bright House customers beginning post-close. 
Excluding transition CapEx in both periods, our first quarter CapEx was up by just over $39 million, or 12%, driven primarily by our investments in product development and the end-year timing of the fleet purchases, which falls into the support capital line. For 2016, excluding the impact of transition CapEx and the pending acquisitions, we expect our CapEx as a percentage of revenue to continue to decline at Charter year-over-year.
First quarter free cash flow was negative $61 million and the year-over-year decline was primarily driven by the higher cash interest on our transactions-related debt and escrow, and from higher CapEx for the reasons I just outlined.
If you exclude the impact of our transaction, specifically, $21 million of operating expense, $53 million of CapEx, $259 million of cash interest in escrow and $14 million of transaction costs and other expenses, our free cash flow adjusted for transaction spend, totaled approximately $280 million, that's up significantly versus last year on the same basis.
As of March 31, our net debt to LTM EBITDA was 4.1x. The $21.8 billion of cash sitting in escrow for our transactions, plus Term Loan A commitments and our combined liquidity at close, fully finances our transactions assuming TWC shareholders elect the $100 cash option. At closing, we still expect to be levered at 4.5x or less on an LTM basis and assuming the first 12 months run rate synergies of approximately $500 million.
In February, we issued $1.7 billion of senior unsecured notes and in April, we issued an additional $1.5 billion of senior unsecured notes. We intend to use the proceeds from these offerings to redeem Charter's currently callable outstanding higher price debt, although part of the proceeds from the February offer could be used to finance our transactions if some of the TWC shareholders were to elect to receive the $115 per share in cash rather than $100.
Turning to the pending transactions. We expect the second quarter will be the first quarter for which we will report our results following close, and I wanted to give you a brief preview on how we expect to report and to mention a few things to better navigate our second quarter results. 
With an anticipated mid-quarter closing, our second quarter results will reflect a full quarter from legacy Charter, plus stub periods for TWC and Bright House, so year-over-year actual comparisons won't really be helpful, but we will provide historical pro formas for the 3 companies under the historical management. We intend to present Charter's quarterly trending schedule with pro forma data, along the lines of what you received today, dating back to the beginning of 2014. 
Moving forward, we'll report similar customer, PSU and revenue data for Charter's 3 legacy entities for at least 5 quarters following close, both separately and, of course, under consolidated basis. This approach is going to allow you to track the development of each of the 3 legacy entities. 
We'll not show expenses or capital expenditures by legacy entity. It's not really practical, given the shared nature of large key items like programming, overhead and significant centralized capital spend.
We'll also continue to report transition expense and capital related to the integration and we'll provide updates in conference calls on certain items, including estimates for the synergies we've realized, so you can better isolate the organic growth of the business. We'll probably do that for about 2 years, beginning in the first full quarter of results. 
Our balance sheet and P&L will also be materially impacted by purchase price accounting and allocation. And part of that will be a significant fair market value step-up of TWC and Bright House assets, reflecting the fair market value of the consideration we provide as of the closing dates. The step-ups will primarily be in PNG, franchises, customer relationships and goodwill. I've heard none of the 3 companies' assets will be stepped-up for s   our tax purposes. As a result of the difference between the stepped-up GAAP basis and the existing tax basis at TWC, there will be a significant increase to our deferred tax liability on our GAAP balance sheet. On a pro forma basis, and as already reflected in our S-4 and other filings, the GAAP basis step-up will also increase Charter's GAAP DNA charges above what the simple addition of historical DNA would be for the 3 legacy entities. 
Purchase price accounting will also likely result in the posting of an opening liability on the balance sheet to reflect an estimate of the out-of-market portion of TWC's RSN distribution agreement with the Dodgers. There would be no change to the TWC cash payments as a result of that accounting, but future P&L expense would be lower as a result.
We'll also modify the value of TWC's legacy debt to it's a fair market value at closing. And the difference between the fair value at closing and the actual principal amount will amortize over the remaining term of each tranche of debt, driving a difference between GAAP and cash interest expense. 
So those are some of the largest key items that will result from purchase accounting, but there are a number of other key post-closing items that are mentioned that will impact the consolidated financials. Our share count, which stands at approximately 112 million shares outstanding today will increase at close as we issue shares to TWC shareholders and to Liberty Broadband. Given that Advance/Newhouse partnership units are exchangeable at anytime, it makes sense for investors to include those partnership units on an as-exchange basis when evaluating Charter's total equity value and any Charter share-based metrics.
Also keep in mind that as part of the transactions, Charter will undergo what we refer to and explain in more detail in our S-4 as the parent merger exchange. This transaction will essentially haircut the number of shares outstanding for the entire company for all shareholders, including Advance/Newhouse partnership units by approximately 10%. 
The parent Merger exchange will be value-neutral to all parties aggregate holdings in Charter, but it will reduce the overall share count of the company both on a shares outstanding basis and on an as-exchange basis, again, by about 10%.
In theory, New Charter stock market price should reflect this reduction in shares with commensurate share price increase on the day New Charter stock begins to trade on the NASDAQ. Slide 22 in the appendix of today's investor presentation should provide investors with a better understanding of Charter's share count and how the shares outstanding change for the parent merger exchange and the Advance/Newhouse unit on an as-exchange basis.
Moving on to some more post-closing, accounting and reporting housekeeping. At close, TWC employees who currently hold TWC stock awards will see those stock awards replaced with New Charter stock awards, which will mirror their current economics. The post closing vesting of these awards will increase stock compensation expense post-closing to reflect the updated fair value of these replacement stock awards as compared to their original grant value. We should also mention that after closing substantially all of the $3 billion valuation allowance, which is posted against legacy Charter's deferred tax assets, is expected to be removed as the use of our NOLs will now be accelerated in Charter's consolidated tax return. 
The legacy Charter deferred tax asset account on the balance sheet today and net income in that quarter were both increased by approximately $3 billion as a onetime benefit. We'll also expense a quarterly charge of approximately $38 million in preferred coupon for Advance/Newhouse's ownership of preferred partnership units. That charge will be reported on a separate line as noncontrolling interest expense.
We'll also have some transaction adviser expenses for both Charter and TWC, which are contingent and payable closing, already disclosed in the S-4 as well as the commitment and placement fees for our financing. And we expect below the line restructuring and termination expenses through the integration process that will post below the EBITDA line as well.
Finally, turning to our tax assets, as we indicated on our last call, we don't expect Charter to be a significant cash tax payer until 2018. And even then, our cash taxes as a percentage of GAAP pretax income should be below statutory rates for several years thereafter. And when I refer to GAAP pretax income, we are excluding the impact of the pending purchase price accounting that we'll have on GAAP depreciation and amortization expense going forward.
We do expect the transactions to trigger a change of ownership under Section 382 of the tax code. And while that change in ownership will again restrict the pace at which NOLs will become available, I don't expect it to negatively impact the net present value of our tax assets similar to last time, as the transactions here will create a larger base of taxable income, ultimately accelerating the utilization of our NOLs versus standalone Charter today. 
Operator, with that, we're ready for questions now.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from John Hodulik from UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from John Hodulik from UBS.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question for Tom. Can we talk a little bit about the migration of the Time Warner Cable base to the new pricing and packaging? You mentioned it a little bit on the call, but over what time period did you expect this to take place? And what kind of impact
componenttext: Question for Tom. Can we talk a little bit about the migration of the Time Warner Cable base to the new pricing and packaging? You mentioned it a little bit on the call, but over what time period did you expect this to take place? And what kind of impact can we expect on the top line of the new assets?

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it'll take some time to roll out new pricing and packaging across Time Warner and Bright House. The plan is to, as I described, to continue the all-digital project that is going on currently at Time Warner and to initiate a similar project at Bright
componenttext: Well, it'll take some time to roll out new pricing and packaging across Time Warner and Bright House. The plan is to, as I described, to continue the all-digital project that is going on currently at Time Warner and to initiate a similar project at Bright House in the Tampa area and as we do that to roll out new pricing and packaging behind it. We also intend to launch within a matter of 4 months or so new pricing and packaging against the parts of the company that has already gone all-digital. And to get it rolled out over the period of time it takes to do all-digital, which could take through the end of '18.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And through that period, do you expect any meaningful change on the -- Time Warner Cable just posted a pretty solid top line growth number, I mean, do you expect any impact on the growth rate of those assets?
componenttext: And through that period, do you expect any meaningful change on the -- Time Warner Cable just posted a pretty solid top line growth number, I mean, do you expect any impact on the growth rate of those assets?

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, yes. We're going to have to integrate those assets into our packaging and pricing and we're going to have costs associated with that. And we -- our objective is to actually accelerate the growth rate. And in order to do that, we're going to spend
componenttext: I think, yes. We're going to have to integrate those assets into our packaging and pricing and we're going to have costs associated with that. And we -- our objective is to actually accelerate the growth rate. And in order to do that, we're going to spend more capital by going all-digital and putting 2-way interactive boxes on every outlet. And we're going to package in such a way that we think we get longer-term revenue growth and get that revenue growth over a longer period of time with the quality of the products that we're selling into the markets. So they've done very well, which we're very pleased with. The assets are in better shape than we'd even planned for, which is a great relief. But we do -- we do have plans to spend money and spend capital in order to have a uniform product that we think creates a longer-term growth prospect that will produce consistent long-term growth rates.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bryan Kraft of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Bryan Kraft of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I had one question in the context of CapEx. The JV that you have with Arris, can you talk about the full scope of the JV and the advantages it brings to Charter, I guess, both from an innovation standpoint? And also, how it impacts your ability t
componenttext: I guess, I had one question in the context of CapEx. The JV that you have with Arris, can you talk about the full scope of the JV and the advantages it brings to Charter, I guess, both from an innovation standpoint? And also, how it impacts your ability to more efficiently deploy capital? And then, I just had one other question, just on the synergies. Chris, based on what you were saying about timing, it sounds like you expect to fully realize the synergies on a run-rate basis in about 2 years, is that the right interpretation of what you had said?

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me start with the second one. No, that's not the right interpretation, although I'm glad you asked it, because it should highlight for people. I was giving a commitment that we'll report that amount on a going backwards basis of how much is realize
componenttext: So let me start with the second one. No, that's not the right interpretation, although I'm glad you asked it, because it should highlight for people. I was giving a commitment that we'll report that amount on a going backwards basis of how much is realized inside the quarter for 2 years. It could end up being longer depending on where we're actually at. I think what we said in the past is that we expect synergies could be over the course of 3 years to be fully baked into the actuals and there wasn't a change of where I think I could be. So after 2 years, we'll evaluate where we are, but I wanted to give people some clarity about how we were going to report the business in the upcoming 2 years at a minimum. On the ActiveVideo JV that we have with Arris, it's a productive relationship that we have, both with the management team and ActiveVideo as well as Arris who runs 65%. We have a couple of board seats on that investment. We're treated as an independent third-party vendor inside the relationship with ActiveVideo. So I guess, the benefit would be the ability to see what the pipeline of product that they have coming in the future and to have oversight in terms of how that's being developed elsewhere. But we saw an attractive product that we were using amongst other vendors in our Spectrum Guide platform and we thought it was an interesting equity investment, but also a strategic importance to Charter.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And to further answer your question, that ActiveVideo technology platform allows us to use existing set-top boxes and put a state-of-the-art user interface on those already deployed boxes and not have to replace those boxes, so that they essentially becom
componenttext: And to further answer your question, that ActiveVideo technology platform allows us to use existing set-top boxes and put a state-of-the-art user interface on those already deployed boxes and not have to replace those boxes, so that they essentially become state-of-the-art boxes. And that's the capital advantage of having that vendor relationship.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Vijay Jayant from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Vijay Jayant from Evercore ISI.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple, please. First on synergies, now that the deal is pretty much done. We've always thought that $800 million was kind of conservative. Is there a new view on that? And is it fair to still assume that programming step downs on the Charter base will
componenttext: A couple, please. First on synergies, now that the deal is pretty much done. We've always thought that $800 million was kind of conservative. Is there a new view on that? And is it fair to still assume that programming step downs on the Charter base will happen pretty much immediately on the deal closing? And then just on the all-digital plan, I think -- I've estimated that there's about 13 million, 14 million DTAs and analog boxes within the Time Warner Cable and Bright House. Is that sort of the right base that we could see being transitioned to all-digital?

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe I'll give the first 2. We can tag team the third. On the $800 million, I think there was a general misconception right from the get-go is what we call synergies. $800 million was a 3-year run rate of transaction synergies. What we don't include in t
componenttext: Maybe I'll give the first 2. We can tag team the third. On the $800 million, I think there was a general misconception right from the get-go is what we call synergies. $800 million was a 3-year run rate of transaction synergies. What we don't include in that is the amount of operating synergies that come from taking a different philosophy towards pricing and packaging and insourcing service and lowering the amount of transactions. So the transaction synergies, we're not giving an update on our thoughts around that other than we think that it was -- other than to say that we always thought it was conservative. We still do. But that's really tied to the elimination of duplicate overhead programming and other transaction-related synergies of just putting the companies together, it's not a change in the operating strategies, which is how you get additional profitability per capacity over time. So one can argue and say, well, the synergies are obviously, much, much higher than the $800 million, and I would agree with that. But that's really a chance in the way that the businesses are operating as opposed to M&A transaction synergies, which is what the $800 million refers to. On programming timing, yes, we believe we'll step into the Time Warner Cable rate card in the appropriate places effectively at close. And on DTAs, I don't have...

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure that -- I can't verify that your number is correct off the top of my head. So -- but our plan will be to let them come out of the marketplace in a natural away, and we're not going to go force them out. So as we transect business and move peo
componenttext: I'm not sure that -- I can't verify that your number is correct off the top of my head. So -- but our plan will be to let them come out of the marketplace in a natural away, and we're not going to go force them out. So as we transect business and move people into new pricing and packaging, we'll get the new customer base on the new pricing platform, a two-way boxes on every outlet, so they'll begin to [indiscernible] in some of these markets for years to come.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ben Swinburne of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Ben Swinburne of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, I don't know if you'd be willing to shed some light for us on the SEC's approach around the set-top box, NPRM and also the special access noise that's been going on lately given how much time you spent in D.C. over the last few months and year, if yo
componenttext: Tom, I don't know if you'd be willing to shed some light for us on the SEC's approach around the set-top box, NPRM and also the special access noise that's been going on lately given how much time you spent in D.C. over the last few months and year, if you could just tell us how you think those 2 may or may not impact the new company going forward? And then, Chris, cost-to-service was, I think, down in the quarter, I don't know if that's a clean number, if there were anything onetime in there. But I'd love if you could just talk about the operating leverage you're seeing in the existing Charter Business, since that's obviously an important lens for us to look at as we think about the new company down the road?

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Ben, you're right, I spent a lot of time there, but focused on other things. The -- we -- from Charter's point of view, we don't charge for modems and we try to keep our box prices low relatively speaking and we have made our applications available
componenttext: Well, Ben, you're right, I spent a lot of time there, but focused on other things. The -- we -- from Charter's point of view, we don't charge for modems and we try to keep our box prices low relatively speaking and we have made our applications available on other set-top boxes that consumers could purchase. And so from a -- if you just look at it as a people being concerned about the price of boxes, we think that our operating practice is fit with that goal. The control of copyright and the control of privacy are real issues and we have strong views that they should be protected. With regard to special access, we haven't seen the full scope of that yet, only what's been publicized. And we're a nascent player in that market with the whole cable industry, I think, is less than 10% penetrated against that very large marketplace. And so it seems premature to me to be thinking about regulating a new entrant to a marketplace.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on the cost of service, no, there's not any onetime benefit that's sitting inside the number, that's real operating leverage, if you want to use that term. It is directly a result of lower service calls to the call centers and significantly lower serv
componenttext: And on the cost of service, no, there's not any onetime benefit that's sitting inside the number, that's real operating leverage, if you want to use that term. It is directly a result of lower service calls to the call centers and significantly lower service truck rolls out in the field. And so what that means is that your ability to have a larger number of customers with a higher amount of revenue and a lower underlying operating cost because you have fewer calls and truck rolls taking place. That continues to improve at Charter. And we've just made some additional changes that Tom mentioned in terms of stopping to do hard disconnects now that we have the plant secured with [indiscernible]...

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
