headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Michelle, and I will be your operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to Charter's Third Quarter 2016 Investor Call. [Operator Instructions]I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Stefan Anninger. Ple
componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Michelle, and I will be your operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to Charter's Third Quarter 2016 Investor Call. [Operator Instructions]
I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Stefan Anninger. Please go ahead.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Michelle. Good morning, and welcome to Charter's Third Quarter 2016 Investor Call. Presentation that accompanies this call can be found on our website, ir.charter.com, under the Financial Information section.Before we proceed, I would like to re
componenttext:
Thanks, Michelle. Good morning, and welcome to Charter's Third Quarter 2016 Investor Call. Presentation that accompanies this call can be found on our website, ir.charter.com, under the Financial Information section.
Before we proceed, I would like to remind you that there are a number of risk factors and other cautionary statements contained in our SEC filings, including our most recent proxy statement and Forms 10-K and 10-Q. We will not review those risk factors and other cautionary statements on this call; however, we encourage you to read them carefully. Various remarks that we make on this call concerning expectations, predictions, plans and prospects constitute forward-looking statements. These forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ from historical or anticipated results. Any forward-looking statements reflect management's current view only, and Charter undertakes no obligation to revise or update such statements or to make additional forward-looking statements in the future.
During the course of today's call, we will be referring to non-GAAP measures as defined and reconciled in our earnings materials. These non-GAAP measures as defined by Charter may not be comparable to measures with similar titles used by other companies.
We will also refer to pro forma results. While our transactions closed on May 18, 2016, these pro forma results present information regarding the combined operations as if our transactions had closed at the beginning of the earliest period presented in order to provide a more useful discussion of our results. Please refer to the pro forma disclosures throughout today's materials, including the reconciliations provided in Exhibit 99.1 to our Form 10-Q filed today. Except for the third quarter of 2016 and unless otherwise specified, all customer and financial data referred to on this call are pro forma for the transactions as if they had closed at the beginning of the earliest period referenced. Please also note that all growth rate noted on this call and in the presentation are calculated on a year-over-year basis, unless otherwise specified.
Joining me on today's call are Tom Rutledge, Chairman and CEO; and Chris Winfrey, our CFO. And with that, I'll turn the call over to Tom.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Stefan.Since the closing of our transaction in May, we've been focused on quickly integrating our new assets. Integration is going well, and we were able to continue to develop new services and capabilities at the same time we integrate. In l
componenttext:
Thank you, Stefan.
Since the closing of our transaction in May, we've been focused on quickly integrating our new assets. Integration is going well, and we were able to continue to develop new services and capabilities at the same time we integrate. In late September, we began deploying our marketing strategy in the Time Warner Cable footprint, including Texas and California. That process includes launching new service -- [ph] new pricing and packaging and the rebranding of our services as Spectrum. As a result, we're already seeing better sales in those markets.
As expected, these launches in September had a little effect on Q3 results. However, later this month, we will roll out Spectrum in our New York City and Florida markets. By year end, we will have branded over 50% of our service area as Spectrum. We expect to be through [ph] all Time Warner Cable and Bright House markets by the spring of next year with customers and financial growth benefits following over time like they have at pre-deal [ph] Charter.
On the small and medium business side, we will launch full Spectrum SMB product and pricing and packaging in Time Warner Cable and Bright House passings in mid-2017. Similar to residential, we will offer SMB products that are better than what the telcos offer at lower prices, driving customer growth in the same way we have at pre-deal Charter since launching SMB pricing and packaging in the early 2015. We're just beginning to modify business practices, policies and processes, which take time, and our goal is to avoid service disruptions. 
Insourcing 20,000 employees will require upfront investments to train, house and equip our own personnel. There'll be a period of time when the productivity of those workers will be relatively low, preventing us from immediately reducing our outsourced workforce. Over time, however, the productivity of our insourced employee base will grow and transactions will decline, allowing us to change our insourced service mix faster. So we will invest more in each customer transaction, driving higher-quality work. That higher-quality work drives transactions out of the business, lowering transaction cost per dollar [ph] of revenue and per customer relationship. The operating and financial results of our strategy have been demonstrated at pre-deal Charter, and we expect the same types of results for the new company. We'll also complete the all-digital transition at Time Warner Cable and Bright House over the next 2 years.
Aside from the [ph] integration, we remain focused on product and network development. Over the next 5 years or so, with relatively small infrastructure investments, our network will be able to deliver symmetrical multi-gigabit speeds with high-compute and low-latency capabilities to all 50 million homes and businesses in our footprint.
In addition to residential and SMB offerings, we will serve the enterprise marketplace with increasingly sophisticated and advanced products. The opportunity is meaningful, and our addressable footprint is approximately $20 billion of annual enterprise spend, and today, we're capturing less than 10% of that spend.
There's also a large opportunity for us in the advanced advertising space. Our 2-way interactive plant allows for highly efficient household addressability, and we're testing new platforms, which will allow advertisers to better target, measure and reach consumers at the household level.
Finally, mobility remains an area of significant opportunity for Charter and the cable industry more broadly. We are already a significant wireless provider through our in- and out-of-home WiFi footprint, and we intend to activate our MVNO agreement with Verizon. In the near term, our goals with mobility are to drive more customer growth and extend customer life by offering an attractively priced product bundle.
Over the long term, our goals will broaden. We believe there will be opportunities for us to develop new services as higher frequency Spectrum, both licensed and unlicensed, becomes available. Ultimately, our goals are consistent for any new businesses that we develop, to grow our overall business more quickly and to track [ph] more shareholder value.
Before I turn the call over to Chris Winfrey who will cover the quarter in more detail, I wanted to highlight that we had a very strong quarter of financial results. We grew revenue by over 7% year-over-year and EBIT growth of over 14%, in part driven by transaction synergies, which are quickly benefiting our P&L, but also driven by the continued strength of our core operations at legacy Charter.
Third quarter customer results were more inconsistent with good performance at legacy Charter and Bright House with higher churn and downgrades from the Time Warner Cable markets, as we expected, given the way Time Warner Cable had marketed promotional pricing. Until our Spectrum pricing and packaging is launched across the newly acquired service areas, we continue to expect higher levels of churn and downgrades where Time Warner Cable is the operator.
Pre-deal Charter results continue to reflect the multiyear effect of our operating plans, including 6.2% residential and SMB customer growth over the last 12 months, with 9.7% Internet customer growth, 70,000 video net additions and 7.2% revenue growth without relying on rate increases. At the same time, service transactions and churn in those areas continue to come down.
So our growth plan is working, and our integration remains on or ahead of schedule. Nothing we have seen internally or externally has changed our optimism regarding our long-term business opportunities and growth prospects. 
Chris, I'll turn the call to you.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. On our last quarter's call, I spent a lot of time discussing the effect of purchase accounting on the financials and the presentation of pro forma results. So I won't go through all that again, but last quarter's presentation and transfer reg
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. On our last quarter's call, I spent a lot of time discussing the effect of purchase accounting on the financials and the presentation of pro forma results. So I won't go through all that again, but last quarter's presentation and transfer regarding accounting items remain helpful to the investors.
As Tom had mentioned, [indiscernible] refer to the third quarter 2016 actual results versus prior year pro forma results as comparisons to third quarter 2015 actual service is [ph] helpful. 
The customer and passings data that you see in today's materials continue to be based on legacy company definitions. And in a full -- few quarters' time, we'll recast customer data and the trending schedules using the same common definitions. Until then, certain data like penetration and ARPU
remain relative for legacy entity trends, but they're less helpful in comparing one entity to another.
Turning to customers and PSUs. During the third quarter, total customer relationships grew year-over-year by 5.1%, including 4.5% at legacy TWC, 6.2% at legacy Charter and 5.9% at legacy Bright House.
As Slide 8 shows, we grew residential PSUs by 336,000 versus 605,000 on a pro forma basis last year. The lower year-over-year PSU net adds was primarily driven by fewer voice net additions this quarter, partly due to a low-price voice offer in TWC markets in prior year quarters, which is now resulting in higher voice downgrades and relationship churn.
Over [ph] last year, TWC residential video customers declined by about 0.5%. Pre-deal Charter grew its residential video customer base by 1.2%, and Bright House lost about 2.6% of its residential video customers. Quarterly video customer performance improved year-over-year at pre-deal Charter and at Bright House, while TWC video net loss was 54,000 worse than last year, primarily driven by an increase in video downgrade activity, given legacy pricing and packaging issues.
So in total, we lost 47,000 residential video customers in the quarter, primarily from the net losses at TWC.
In residential Internet, we added a total of 350,000 customers versus 369,000 last year. Our total residential Internet customer base grew by 1.6 million customers or 8.2% over the past year.
In voice, we grew customers by 33,000 versus 256,000 last year, largely driven by higher churn at TWC for the reasons I already mentioned.
Over the last year, total pro forma residential customers grew by 1.1 million or by 4.8%. And over the same period, residential revenue per customer was up by about 1.8%, nearly all of which was driven by TWC rate increases early in the year and step-ups, which impacted unit growth.
Slide 9 shows our customer growth combined with our ARPU growth resulted in year-over-year pro forma residential revenue growth of 6.7%.
Total commercial revenue, SMB and enterprise combined grew by 12.1%, a bit slower than last quarter, driven by lower sales charter [ph] growth and one-time benefited [ph] nano site last year.
Finally, advertising was up 12.1% and absent [ph] political advertising, revenue grew roughly 2%.
In total, third quarter pro forma revenue for the company was up 7.4% year-over-year.
Looking at total revenue growth by each of our legacy companies, TWC revenue grew by 7.7%, with nearly half of residential growth still coming from rate; [ph] pre-deal Charter grew by 7.2% driven predominantly by continued customer growth; and Bright House revenue grew by 6.6% with the Florida markets continuing [ph] to do well.
Within operating expense in both current and historical periods, we've reclassified a number of operating expense items between lines. [ph] And as I mentioned last quarter, we do expect some ongoing remapping [ph] expenses as we move the expense categories to the correct business unit in our operating structure. Total operating expenses grew by $234 million or 3.8% year-over-year, with the transition expense accounting for $32 million of our total OpEx this quarter. Programming increased 8.2% year-over-year, driven by contractual rate increases, partially offset by transaction synergies. I expect our programming line and year-over-year programming comparisons to be more representative on a pro forma basis by Q4 or at least by Q1.
Turning to regulatory, connectivity and produced content expense, these direct costs were down about 3% year-over-year, in part due to the purchase accounting adjustment made to the Dodgers contract that I discussed last quarter. The Dodgers [ph] costs are only expensed during the regular [indiscernible] both in the past and today.
Costs to service to customers declined by about 2% despite overall customer growth of 5.1%, which reflects lower service transactions at legacy Charter, the lack of all-digital activity at TWC this quarter versus last year's third quarter and some benefit through [ph] less physical disconnects in all digital markets.
And other expenses grew by 7.9% driven by higher corporate administrative labor costs, including advertising sales costs, enterprise sales and higher year-over-year IT spend at legacy TWC. Expense was partly offset by overhead reductions.
Adjusted EBITDA, which excludes noncash share-based compensation, grew by 14.5%, and excluding transition costs, adjusted EBITDA grew by 15.1%. That growth includes continued growth in TWC [ph] Charter, excluding synergies at a level well above revenue growth. And absent transaction synergies and merger accounting effects and labor for all-digital strategy TWC [ph] in 2015, consolidated Charter adjusted EBITDA was probably growing just about -- just above the total revenue growth rate.
We've identified nearly $90 million of hard [ph] transaction synergies realized within the third quarter, which had a positive impact on the financial statements and was growing through the quarter. These various small projects have naturally come under review. There are additional benefits outside of the $90 million inside the quarter to the income statement, some of which could drive sustainably lower spend on discretionary initiatives, which will be harder to track definitively, and some of which may just be a temporary pause.[ph]
Going the opposite direction, some overhead groups continue to be double staffed [ph] as we prepare to transition systems and processes starting in Q4 and for many areas like going [ph] provisioning, IT and engineering, that will persist into 2017. So net-net, these puts and takes will continue for a while. But there are roughly $350 million of annualized hard [ph] transaction synergies already in the Q3 numbers, and we've completely identified $700 million in runway [ph] transaction synergies, which should be achieved at the first anniversary of the closing.
[indiscernible] qualities, these estimates continues to improve over time, and we continue to expect to significantly exceed the $800 million target after 3 years.
Legacy Charter, without any synergy benefit, continues to be a good proxy for how we expect subscribers and financials to develop once our Spectrum pricing and packaging is fully deployed. Over the next few quarters, our operating results will reflect reversing certain product and packaging strategies, in particular, TWC, which, in our view, are not sustainable given high promotional roll-offs and the [ph] rate increases, high customer equipment fees, including modem [ph] fees, all coupled with complex and stacked [ph] offers. Our goal is to transition to the new pricing and packaging in a revenue-accretive manner, but the revenue growth rate [ph] will probably be lower in the sales [ph] Spectrum pricing and packaging is fully deployed, relationship growth accelerates and the systematic approach to roll-offs and retention are in place.
In addition, we expect to spend more OpEx for service operations in [ph] capital for all-digital through 2018, similar to legacy Charter. But what will be different in the legacy Charter experience is that we will have transaction synergies in growth with legacy Charter operations for the financial [ph] incremental spending. And there's more for [indiscernible] at Bright House base that's already been digitized and we have lower unit cost on boxes.
Turning to net income on Slide 11. We generated $189 million of net income attributable to Charter shareholders in the third quarter versus $2 million on a pro forma basis last year with the growth driven by higher adjusted EBITDA and a gain on financial instruments from currency movements on our pound debt and related hedging. That's partially offset by transaction-related expense, including severance expense and higher depreciation and amortization driven by purchase price accounting stuff ups. 
Turning to Slide 12, capital expenditures totaled $1.75 billion including $109 million of transition spend. Excluding transition CapEx, our third quarter CapEx was down by $36 million year-over-year, about 2% driven by 1 all-digital spending at TWC, primarily on CPE which did not recur in the third quarter this year; two, part of your support capital spending at TWC, including real estate investments and network facilities, both of which were offset by investments in product development, which fall in the scalable infrastructure. 
Looking ahead, we expect our annual capital spending to rise once we restart all-digital in 2017. 
Slide 13 shows we generated $1 billion in free cash flow in the third quarter versus $208 million of actual, not pro forma, free cash flow in the third quarter last year. That growth was largely driven by higher adjusted EBITDA and the close of our transactions. And although we don't provide pro forma free cash flow for the third quarter of 2015, on a pro forma basis, adjusted EBITDA less CapEx grew by 28% in the third quarter versus the prior year. 
We finished the third quarter with $60.2 billion in principal amount of debt. Run rate annualized cash interest expense was $3.3 billion, whereas our P&L interest expense would suggest a $2.9 billion annual run rate. The P&L difference, cash stems from the revaluation of required TWC debt on our GAAP balance sheet is part of purchase accounting. 
As of the end of the third quarter, total net debt to the last 12 months pro forma adjusted EBITDA was 4.2x. Our long-term target leverage remains at 4 to 4.5x, and we continue to target the lower end of that range. We're deleveraging rapidly, and we continue -- and we can use that excess capacity in a number of ways. The priorities remain investment in the business, accretive M&A when available, returning capital to shareholders in the form share repurchases. 
During the third quarter, we repurchased 1.1 million in Charter shares for $281 million at an average price of about $267 per share. Share repurchase activity will continue to depend on market conditions and other potential uses of capital, and we'll be opportunistic, similar to what we did in 2011, where we provided liquidity in size and fair priced institutional sellers. Our goal is to retain full strategic flexibility and not become trapped by formulary capital allocation guidance on buybacks. 
Finally, turning to our capital structure on Slide 15. We estimate that the total value of those assets is an excess of $6 billion and is comprised of our excess basis, marginal wells and a valuable tax-sharing agreement with Advance/Newhouse. We don't currently expect to be a material cash income taxpayer until at least 2018, maybe not until 2019, and even then, our cash taxes as a percentage of GAAP pretax income, excluding the impact of higher G&A from purchase accounting, should be below statutory rates for 7 years thereafter. 
Operator, we are now ready for Q&A.

componenttext: Two questions on wireless, if I could. One, just a clarification. You said that you were going to trigger the MVNO with Verizon. Has Verizon confirmed the full availability of the MVNO? The transferability from TWC to a new owner? And if so, are there any restrictions on the footprints that you can use it then? And then second, so you disclosed you started buying back stock. Is there any interaction between spending that you might do on wireless at the rate at which you repurchase shares? I saw an SEC filing in which you indicated some expectation of having your own facilities in wireless.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: So the first question, I don't with truthful discussions with Verizon, but I don't want to characterize them beyond that. And with regard to our licenses, yes, we've asked the SEC for the right to experiment with what people call wave technologies in several markets so that we can learn how to use those products to our advantage competitively.

componenttext:
{newP}
A follow-up first and then a question. Chris I know you don't want to get trapped into talking -- guiding on a buyback, but you talked about providing liquidity to market in the past, whereas this time you were buying in what was a fairly high period of demand at relatively high prices. How do you think about the buyback in terms of being opportunistic? And how do the Board come up with $715 million over a 6-month period?

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't have getting into our board's thinking, but that was the number that we got, and obviously management like as much flexibility as we could have. And the opportunistic part being in 2011, there were periods of disruption, where institutional invest
componenttext: I don't have getting into our board's thinking, but that was the number that we got, and obviously management like as much flexibility as we could have. And the opportunistic part being in 2011, there were periods of disruption, where institutional investors were able to provide them liquidity. There's all the other traditional ways of going back and buying back stock, whether there's high market demand, low market demand. At the end of the day, it's just on what you think the growth profile of the company is and where the stock will be several years out as opposed to the next few months. If you have views on what you think the stock is worth over a multiyear period, does it look attractive, and we thought it did, and we executed on some buybacks under that authority.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And second CapEx is fairly low. I think you are delaying the you talked about delaying all the digital migration. Should we expect that to be up a little bit in 4Q as you get ready for more digital conversions? And then if you can give us any kind o
componenttext: Okay. And second CapEx is fairly low. I think you are delaying the you talked about delaying all the digital migration. Should we expect that to be up a little bit in 4Q as you get ready for more digital conversions? And then if you can give us any kind of preview on '17, where it might be versus the $6.9 billion that was outlined in the proxy.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the proxy was based on a business plans of nearly 2 years ago, so frankly I don't even remember what the number was. There's nothing that's changed in our thoughts about the trajectory of CapEx over time when we close 6 months later and if we see opp
componenttext: Yes, the proxy was based on a business plans of nearly 2 years ago, so frankly I don't even remember what the number was. There's nothing that's changed in our thoughts about the trajectory of CapEx over time when we close 6 months later and if we see opportunities for investments I don't want to be tethered to what we were laying out then, the trajectory is the same. And for 2017, I don't even know how much we're doing in terms of all-digital in 2017 versus 2018. That's going to be one of the large drivers there. We're not going to get into the mode of being trapped by that CapEx guidance either. We expect the capital intensity to decline over time once we get through the all-digital.

componenttext: Yes. We haven't actually done our budgets yet. So we don't know what we're going to spend in 2017.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chris, just going back to the synergy and investments sort of trying to maybe help us think about the cadence. On the program cost side, did you guys are you basically recognizing or have you already gotten all of the benefits from rolling Time Warner Cab
componenttext: Chris, just going back to the synergy and investments sort of trying to maybe help us think about the cadence. On the program cost side, did you guys are you basically recognizing or have you already gotten all of the benefits from rolling Time Warner Cable's car. You talked about fourth quarter being a little more of a normalized number, but can you give us some color as to why. And on the other side of it, your slide, or the number that shows in sourcing, it looks like the insourcing has started. I don't know if you can give us a sense you can call it qualitatively or how far along you are in terms of hiring those 20,000 people or that's the most still ahead of us. And then I have a follow-up for Tom.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are not intentionally getting into to a line by line as it relates to the synergy targets or what's been realized, because frankly, from an investor perspective, I don't know that it matters that much. There's one thing talk about the one-time synergie
componenttext: We are not intentionally getting into to a line by line as it relates to the synergy targets or what's been realized, because frankly, from an investor perspective, I don't know that it matters that much. There's one thing talk about the one-time synergies and another is thing to talk about the growth curve programming cost once you have that synergy over a multiyear period and those are the really listings items. So for all the obvious reasons, we're not going to go line by line. I think the keeping for investors understand is that we started off I think when we announced the transaction thinking it would be around $400 million in the first year, at the end of the first year annualized. [indiscernible] 500, last quarter it was at 600. This quarter, we are confirming that it's $700 million at the end of year 1 run rate, and that we're going to significantly exceed the $800 million original target for the run rate at the end of 3 year. So that's what really matters, and that's what different from Charter is going to help us fund a lot of the investments that we're doing and despite different net growth curve financially for the new company. From a programming expense line perspective, I guess the only thing I would tell you is, one, even though you stepped into our curve that has nothing this give you an indication of what that slope was and the growth rate could continue to be high on the rate card you stepped into. But we're not occurring against the contractual rate card, which we're doing. Beyond that, I'll just leave it at that. And for all the obvious reasons, we're not going to go much deeper into the topic.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, got it. And then just Tom just going back to your comments at enterprise, we get that a lot from a lot of the cable operators and it's obviously a big opportunity. But also one that I don't think we've seen any one really cracked the code on yet. Do
componenttext: Yes, got it. And then just Tom just going back to your comments at enterprise, we get that a lot from a lot of the cable operators and it's obviously a big opportunity. But also one that I don't think we've seen any one really cracked the code on yet. Do you believe you can build all the expertise and a product offering, sales force, et cetera, to go after enterprise meaningfully? Or do you think you need to buy assets, either network assets or expertise, to really capture that when you look at it what seems to be I think you said a $20 billion opportunity or footprint?

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I do think we can build it, and I think that we can change the definition of the product set that works from that marketplace as well, coming at it from a nonincumbent perspective. But one of the advantages of the new company and the new footprint is the
componenttext: I do think we can build it, and I think that we can change the definition of the product set that works from that marketplace as well, coming at it from a nonincumbent perspective. But one of the advantages of the new company and the new footprint is the regionality that has been picked up in terms of our asset base. Previously, Charter was less of a percentage of the DMA in most markets that we operated in. And as a result of that, we have marketing and efficiencies. We couldn't use mass media in a lot of cases. And the same effect actually impedes enterprise growth, because of the regional nature of a lot of enterprises and the multi-site  facilities that larger enterprises have and the inability to serve those consistently when you have a spindly footprint. And so the improvement in the footprint actually improves the opportunity that the enterprise market presents to us as well as the fact that -- I mean, the big news is, we have great technologies, we have the ability to put those technologies everywhere we operate, and we're really underpenetrated. And to me, that's a lot of upside.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: Just referring to your presentation on Page 4. Based on the time line set out, it sort of appears that your KPI gross adds should start increasing starting in 4Q, although you still have the churn associated with Time Warner Cable as you called out. And then ARPU step-up should start really in 4Q '17 given the box that you expect. But sort of looking at your insourcing, it sort of looks like 3 years, but where in that cycle does the duplicative costs start rolling off? Because from what I remember on the Head of the Charter time line looks like a 6-quarter period for elevated cost. Is that similarly the arc we should be thinking about for the new intervention?

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Vijay, I want to lay out our model for you here, but I can't. I think what I would tell you is that the fourth quarter comment you made about volume significantly ramping R&D in the fourth quarter, is I don't see that in the cards. Most of what we're doin
componenttext: Vijay, I want to lay out our model for you here, but I can't. I think what I would tell you is that the fourth quarter comment you made about volume significantly ramping R&D in the fourth quarter, is I don't see that in the cards. Most of what we're doing perspective pricing and packaging isn't beginning until mid-November and through December. So that focus to the marketplace and even then, it's only half of the acquired footprint that we've taken through Spectrum pricing and packaging, so I think we'll be getting ahead of ourselves. I think it's fair to start looking at business and taking product conservatively once Spectrum pricing and packaging is fully deployed across all the markets, and that's the right time to start thinking through. Already, we've been special pricing manufacturing, we are seeing uplift in sales that's material and what we would expect what we saw at Charter. As it relates to these different initiatives I described on the OpEx side, the curve can look a lot like Charter, offsetting that is going to be the fact that we have transaction synergies here, which we did not have in any previous experience, which will buffer that. And in addition to that, you have legacy Charter, which is still large portion of the footprint that's growing at a very fast pace, not just from customer relationships and -- but because of service transactions are coming down or EBITDA growth last time that we can really look at it on a completely standalone basis far outstrip the revenue growth. I mentioned that was without taking so I'm going to say it again and everybody's focused on how much ARPU can you get, but this isn't an ARPU-driven strategy. It's a customer growth-driven strategy and. It's one that's designed to take transaction out of the business. We did get some growth over time at legacy Charter, it will happen here, too, but that's not going to define our success one way or another.

And then secondly, on the sub losses, you said that you'd see the dislocation in Time Warner Cable through the repackaging and repricing. Do things get better or worse from here? Is there some comp that we get over? Is this 60,000 number a good number going forward for that time being?

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

Is the level of losses that we saw this quarter about right through that period? headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. We're working on ways of moderating that simultaneously to the rollout of pricing and packaging. Even if we weren't rolling out pricing and packaging, which has a positive benefit to churn, we've done other things in our whole relationship process, wh
componenttext: No. We're working on ways of moderating that simultaneously to the rollout of pricing and packaging. Even if we weren't rolling out pricing and packaging, which has a positive benefit to churn, we've done other things in our whole relationship process, which is difficult to do during a transition process, but we are making changes where we can to the benefit of the consumer and trying to preserve the customer base while we roll out new pricing and packaging. So I would say that the number this quarter's a proxy for all future quarters until pricing and packaging is rolled out. But pricing and packaging will be fully rolled out by [indiscernible] and the question then is how fast does that flow through the business in a corrective way. But if you look at what we did at Charter, the substantial amount of the customer base turns over every year into new pricing and packaging through both Charter activity and through operator activity. And so it is a difficult thing to model, but we're coming at both ways, both from a premium value proposition and the pricing and packaging we have and doing those smart things that you can do with an existing customer base that's midpriced to move them in the right direction.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have ambitions to make a bigger business, and it's good right now, it's a political season, obviously. But in terms of the new company, we'll immediately start selling data-infused advertising in 2017. And we believe that, that will give us a lif
componenttext: Well, we have ambitions to make a bigger business, and it's good right now, it's a political season, obviously. But in terms of the new company, we'll immediately start selling data-infused advertising in 2017. And we believe that, that will give us a lift over our historic pattern advertising growth, because our products will be worth more to our advertising. And we have a whole series of products that go forward from that. But essentially, we have the ability to put ads where want to put them and to who we want to put them. And that capability should create a different value relationship with advertisers.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the last question on wireless. When you say that it would probably be the end of '17, into '18 before the business is substantial, are you thinking in terms of before you've got a significant number of customers? Or it'll take you that
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the last question on wireless. When you say that it would probably be the end of '17, into '18 before the business is substantial, are you thinking in terms of before you've got a significant number of customers? Or it'll take you that amount of time to roll an offering out because your entire footprint? And then I'm wondering if you could talk in a little more detail about sort of how the economics of the product devolve from what it looks like with the MVNO to where you think it goes as you begin to be able to leverage 5G capabilities in conjunction with the wireless product?

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the answer to your question is the latter. It's really standing up the business that I was talking about. Not having a substantial customer count. And with regard to where it goes, I mean, I think the MVNO is an opportunity to create a high-
componenttext: Well, I think the answer to your question is the latter. It's really standing up the business that I was talking about. Not having a substantial customer count. And with regard to where it goes, I mean, I think the MVNO is an opportunity to create a high-quality product intermixed with our existing high-quality products and create value for customers, and that has a tremendous potential to make the existing business model work better. With regard to how that it's integrated, no, I think 5G type technologies are millimeterwave technologies or small cell high-frequency, high-capacity, low latency wireless networks are products that we will develop. They may or may not be connected to an MVNO relationship or mobility relationship. I think that there are opportunities to create wireless drops in certain cases. So direct wireless connections that require -- that mimic a physical connection to connect malls and other things through the enterprise base and buildings that are not contiguous or a big parking lots, or in some cases, low-density areas that might make some sense. And so the technology platform of these small high-capacity cells can work in a myriad of ways, both as a line extension devices as well as in-home devices that don't necessarily require mobility off property, in office devices that don't require mobility off property, so they don't have to be necessarily developed as a mobile service. So we're going to explore both paths.

How are you thinking about competition from the virtual lower builder potentially in your footprint going forward?

componenttext: They tend to converge over a longer period of time historically. But we see different size, I don't know level. So if there were right different structures people paying different amounts for those and practices diverge, that wouldn't be true, but all of -- historically, it is true they tend to converge over time. With regard to competition, how do we think about it? We think we have great fiscal infrastructure and is underpenetrated. And we have tremendous growth in front of us. We take our competitors seriously, which are to build better products than they do and we think that we'll be able to continue to do that for the first able future. We think will win based on our pricing, packaging and product mix. We think we'll win based on our service business. And we think that the network that we have is underdeveloped in terms of its capabilities.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So with regard to putting packages, generally the product sets that people offer in the market that are less than full services are available to us and we've done experimental. Interestingly, the rate of customers that take full packages from us is increa
componenttext: So with regard to putting packages, generally the product sets that people offer in the market that are less than full services are available to us and we've done experimental. Interestingly, the rate of customers that take full packages from us is increasing. So we're growing our video business and the ratio, the mix of full-service product, the people would think of as a fat package, I guess, is actually increasing. So when we look at our opportunity, if we think there's a niche of market that could work with the products that are available and they're not all -- they all have limitations in terms of being targetable to the non-subscribing marketplace, which generally is lower income and out of the full package market because of their income. And so we have the ability, I think to continue to compete in that space if a product becomes available to us that actually satisfies a segment of the marketplace that's currently unserved. So far, we haven't found that magic mixture. We sowed packages ourselves. We continue to sell them, but the mix is actually going heavier. So I think about it as an evolving landscape, to the extent that content company is want to let us sell in smaller packages that have lower penetrations, we'd be glad to take advantage of that.

And -- but it came a lot closer to the FTC model, not the FCC model, as it's originally proposed. And it's not on purpose, but it's better.

componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Michelle, and I will be your operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to Charter's Third Quarter 2016 Investor Call. [Operator Instructions]
I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Stefan Anninger. Please go ahead.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Michelle. Good morning, and welcome to Charter's Third Quarter 2016 Investor Call. Presentation that accompanies this call can be found on our website, ir.charter.com, under the Financial Information section.Before we proceed, I would like to re
componenttext:
Thanks, Michelle. Good morning, and welcome to Charter's Third Quarter 2016 Investor Call. Presentation that accompanies this call can be found on our website, ir.charter.com, under the Financial Information section.
Before we proceed, I would like to remind you that there are a number of risk factors and other cautionary statements contained in our SEC filings, including our most recent proxy statement and Forms 10-K and 10-Q. We will not review those risk factors and other cautionary statements on this call; however, we encourage you to read them carefully. Various remarks that we make on this call concerning expectations, predictions, plans and prospects constitute forward-looking statements. These forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ from historical or anticipated results. Any forward-looking statements reflect management's current view only, and Charter undertakes no obligation to revise or update such statements or to make additional forward-looking statements in the future.
During the course of today's call, we will be referring to non-GAAP measures as defined and reconciled in our earnings materials. These non-GAAP measures as defined by Charter may not be comparable to measures with similar titles used by other companies.
We will also refer to pro forma results. While our transactions closed on May 18, 2016, these pro forma results present information regarding the combined operations as if our transactions had closed at the beginning of the earliest period presented in order to provide a more useful discussion of our results. Please refer to the pro forma disclosures throughout today's materials, including the reconciliations provided in Exhibit 99.1 to our Form 10-Q filed today. Except for the third quarter of 2016 and unless otherwise specified, all customer and financial data referred to on this call are pro forma for the transactions as if they had closed at the beginning of the earliest period referenced. Please also note that all growth rate noted on this call and in the presentation are calculated on a year-over-year basis, unless otherwise specified.
Joining me on today's call are Tom Rutledge, Chairman and CEO; and Chris Winfrey, our CFO. And with that, I'll turn the call over to Tom.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Stefan.Since the closing of our transaction in May, we've been focused on quickly integrating our new assets. Integration is going well, and we were able to continue to develop new services and capabilities at the same time we integrate. In l
componenttext:
Thank you, Stefan.
Since the closing of our transaction in May, we've been focused on quickly integrating our new assets. Integration is going well, and we were able to continue to develop new services and capabilities at the same time we integrate. In late September, we began deploying our marketing strategy in the Time Warner Cable footprint, including Texas and California. That process includes launching new service -- new pricing and packaging and the rebranding of our services as Spectrum. As a result, we're already seeing better sales in those markets.
As expected, these launches in September had little effect on Q3 results. However, later this month, we will roll out Spectrum in our New York City and Florida markets. By year end, we will have branded over 50% of our service area as Spectrum. We expect to be through all Time Warner Cable and Bright House markets by the spring of next year with customers and financial growth benefits following over time like they have at pre-deal Charter.
On the small and medium business sides, we will launch full Spectrum SMB product and pricing and packaging in Time Warner Cable and Bright House passings in mid-2017. Similar to residential, we will offer SMB products that are better than what the telcos offer at lower prices, driving customer growth in the same way we have at pre-deal Charter since launching SMB pricing and packaging in the early 2015. We're just beginning to modify business practices, policies and processes, which take time, and our goal is to avoid service disruptions.
Insourcing 20,000 employees will require upfront investments to train, house and equip our own personnel. There'll be a period of time when the productivity of those workers will be relatively low, preventing us from immediately reducing our outsourced workforce. Over time, however, the productivity of our insource employee base will grow and transactions will decline, allowing us to change our insource service mix faster. So we will invest more in each customer transaction, driving higher-quality work. That higher-quality work drives transactions out of the business, lowering transaction cost per dollar of revenue and per customer relationship. The operating and financial results of our strategy have been demonstrated at pre-deal Charter, and we expect the same type of results for the new company. We'll also complete the all-digital transition at Time Warner Cable and Bright House over the next 2 years.
Separate from the integration, we remain focused on product and network development. Over the next 5 years or so, with relatively small infrastructure investments, our network will be able to deliver symmetrical multi-gigabit speeds with high-compute and low-latency capabilities to all 50 million homes and businesses in our footprint.
In addition to residential and SMB offerings, we will serve the enterprise marketplace with increasingly sophisticated and advanced products. The opportunity is meaningful, and our addressable footprint is approximately $20 billion of annual enterprise spend, and today, we're capturing less than 10% of that spend.
There's also a large opportunity for us in the advanced advertising space. Our 2-way interactive plant allows for highly efficient household addressability, and we're testing new platforms, which will allow advertisers to better target, measure and reach consumers at the household level.
Finally, mobility remains an area of significant opportunity for Charter and the cable industry more broadly. We are already a significant wireless provider through our in- and out-of-home WiFi footprint, and we intend to activate our MVNO agreement with Verizon. In the near term, our goals with mobility are to drive more customer growth and extend customer life by offering an attractively priced product bundle.
Over the long term, our goals will broaden. We believe there will be opportunities for us to develop new services as higher frequency Spectrum, both licensed and unlicensed, becomes available. Ultimately, our goals are consistent for any new businesses that we develop: to grow our overall business more quickly and to drag more shareholder value.
Before I turn the call over to Chris Winfrey who will cover the quarter in more detail, I wanted to highlight that we had a very strong quarter of financial results. We grew revenue by over 7% year-over-year and EBIT growth of over 14%, in part driven by transaction synergies, which are quickly benefiting our P&L, but also driven by the continued strength of our core operations at legacy Charter.
Third quarter customer results were more inconsistent with good performance at legacy Charter and Bright House with higher churn and downgrades from the Time Warner Cable markets, as we expected, given the way Time Warner Cable had marketed promotional pricing. Until our Spectrum pricing and packaging is launched across the newly acquired service areas, we continue to expect higher levels of churn and downgrades where Time Warner Cable is the operator.
Pre-deal Charter results continue to reflect the multiyear effect of our operating plans, including 6.2% residential and SMB customer growth over the last 12 months, with 9.7% Internet customer growth, 70,000 video net additions and 7.2% revenue growth without relying on rate increases. At the same time, service transactions and churn in those areas continue to come down.
So our growth plan is working, and our integration remains on or ahead of schedule. Nothing we have seen internally or externally has changed our optimism regarding our long-term business opportunities and growth prospects.
Chris, I'll turn the call to you.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. On our last quarter's call, I spent a lot of time discussing the effect of purchase accounting on the financials and the presentation of pro forma results. So I won't go through all that again, but last quarter's presentation and transcript r
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. On our last quarter's call, I spent a lot of time discussing the effect of purchase accounting on the financials and the presentation of pro forma results. So I won't go through all that again, but last quarter's presentation and transcript regarding accounting items remain helpful to the investors.
As Stefan mentioned, note that I'll refer to the third quarter 2016 actual results versus prior year pro forma results as comparisons to the third quarter 2015 actuals aren't so helpful.
The customer and passings data that you see in today's materials continue to be based on legacy company definitions. And in a full -- few quarters' time, we'll recast customer data and the trending schedules using the same common definitions. Until then, certain data like penetration and ARPU
remain relevant for legacy entity trends, but they're less helpful in comparing one entity to another.
Turning to customers and PSUs during the third quarter. Total customer relationships grew year-over-year by 5.1%, including 4.5% at legacy TWC, 6.2% at legacy Charter and 5.9% at legacy Bright House.
As Slide 8 shows, we grew residential PSUs by 336,000 versus 605,000 on a pro forma basis last year. The lower year-over-year PSU net adds was primarily driven by fewer voice net additions this quarter, partly due to a low-price voice offer in TWC markets in prior year quarters, which is now resulting in higher voice downgrades and relationship churn.
Over the last year, TWC residential video customers declined by about 0.5%. Pre-deal Charter grew its residential video customer base by 1.2%, and Bright House lost about 2.6% of its residential video customers. Quarterly video customer performance improved year-over-year at pre-deal Charter and at Bright House, while TWC video net loss was 54,000 worse than last year, primarily driven by an increase in video downgrade activity, given legacy pricing and packaging issues.
So in total, we lost 47,000 residential video customers in the quarter, primarily driven by the losses at TWC.
In residential Internet, we added a total of 350,000 customers versus 369,000 last year. Our total residential Internet customer base grew by 1.6 million customers or 8.2% over the past year.
In voice, we grew customers by 33,000 versus 256,000 last year, largely driven by higher churn at TWC for the reasons I already mentioned.
Over the last year, total pro forma residential customers grew by 1.1 million or by 4.8%. And over the same period, residential revenue per customer was up by about 1.8%, nearly all of which was driven by TWC rate increases early in the year and step-ups, which impacted unit growth.
Slide 9 shows our customer growth combined with our ARPU growth resulted in year-over-year pro forma residential revenue growth of 6.7%.
Total commercial revenue, SMB and enterprise combined grew by 12.1%, a bit slower than last quarter, driven by lower cell tower growth and one-time benefit at NaviSite last year.
Finally, advertising was up 12.1%, and absent political, advertising revenue grew roughly 2%.
In total, third quarter pro forma revenue for the company was up 7.4% year-over-year.
Looking at total revenue growth by each of our legacy companies, TWC revenue grew by 7.7%, with nearly half of residential growth still coming from rate; pre-deal Charter grew by 7.2% driven predominantly by continued customer growth; and Bright House revenue grew by 6.6% with their Florida markets continuing to do well.
Within operating expense in both current and historical periods, we've reclassified a number of operating expense items between lines. And as I mentioned last quarter, we do expect some ongoing remapping of our expenses as we move expense categories to the correct business unit in our operating structure. Total operating expenses grew by $234 million or 3.8% year-over-year, with the transition expense accounting for $32 million of our total OpEx this quarter. Programming increased 8.2% year-over-year driven by contractual rate increases, partially offset by transaction synergies. I expect our programming line and year-over-year programming comparisons to be more representative on a pro forma basis by Q4 or at least by Q1.
Turning to regulatory, connectivity and produced content expense, these direct costs were down about 3% year-over-year, in part due to the purchase accounting adjustment made to the Dodgers contract that I discussed last quarter. The Dodgers' right costs are only expensed during the regular MLB season, both in the past and today.
Costs to service to customers declined by about 2% despite overall customer growth of 5.1%, which reflects lower service transactions at legacy Charter, the lack of all-digital activity at TWC this quarter versus last year's third quarter and some benefit through less physical disconnects in all-digital markets.
And other expenses grew by 7.9% driven by higher corporate administrative labor costs, including advertising sales costs, enterprise sales and higher year-over-year IT spend at legacy TWC. Expense was partly offset by overhead reductions.
Adjusted EBITDA, which excludes noncash share-based compensation, grew by 14.5%, and excluding transition costs, adjusted EBITDA grew by 15.1%. That growth includes continued growth in legacy Charter, excluding synergies at a level well above revenue growth. And absent transaction synergies and merger accounting effects and labor for all-digital sent [ph] at TWC in 2015, consolidated Charter adjusted EBITDA was probably growing just about -- just above the total revenue growth rate.
We've identified nearly $90 million of hard transaction synergies realized within the third quarter, which have a positive impact on the financial statements and was growing through the quarter. These various small projects have naturally come under review. There are additional benefits outside of the $90 million inside the quarter to the income statement, some of which could drive sustainably lower spend on discretionary initiatives, which will be harder to track definitively, and some of which may just be a temporary pause.
Going the opposite direction, some overhead groups continue to be double staffed as we prepare to transition systems and processes starting in Q4 and for many areas like billing, provisioning, IT and engineering, that will persist into 2017. So net-net, those puts and takes will continue for a while. But there were roughly $350 million of annualized hard transaction synergies already in the Q3 numbers, and we've concretely identified $700 million in run rate transaction synergies, which should be achieved at the first anniversary of the closing.
The amount and quality of these estimates continues to improve over time, and we continue to expect to significantly exceed the $800 million target after 3 years.
Legacy Charter, without any synergy benefit, continues to be a good proxy for how we expect subscribers and financials to develop once our Spectrum pricing and packaging is fully deployed. Over the next few quarters, our operating results will reflect reversing certain product and packaging strategies, in particular, TWC, which, in our view, are not sustainable given high promotional roll-offs and annual rate increases, high customer equipment fees, including modem fees, all coupled with complex and stacked offers. Our goal is to transition to the new pricing and packaging in a revenue-accretive manner, but the revenue growth rate at TWC will probably be lower until Spectrum pricing and packaging is fully deployed, relationship growth accelerates and the systematic approach to roll-offs and retention are in place.
In addition, we expect to spend more OpEx for service operations and capital for all-digital through 2018, similar to legacy Charter. But what will be different in the legacy Charter experience is that we will have transaction synergies and growth from legacy Charter operations to finance much of that incremental spending. And there's more of the TWC and Bright House base that's already been digitized, and we have lower unit cost on boxes.
Turning the to net income on Slide 11. We generated $189 million of net income attributable to Charter shareholders in the third quarter versus $2 million on a pro forma basis last year, with the growth driven by higher adjusted EBITDA and a gain on financial instruments from currency movements on our British pound debt and related hedging. That was partially offset by transaction-related expense, including severance expense and higher depreciation and amortization driven by purchase price accounting step-ups.
Turning to Slide 12, capital expenditures totaled $1.75 billion, including $109 million of transition spend. Excluding transition CapEx, our third quarter CapEx was down by $36 million year-over-year or about 2% driven by, one, all-digital spending at TWC, primarily on CPE, which did not recur in the third quarter of this year; two, prior year support capital spending at TWC, including real estate investments and network facilities, both of which were offset by investments in product development, which fall in the scalable infrastructure.
Looking ahead, we expect our annual capital spending to rise once we restart all-digital in 2017.
As Slide 13 shows, we generated $1 billion in free cash flow in the third quarter versus $208 million of actual, not pro forma, free cash flow in the third quarter last year. That growth was largely driven by higher adjusted EBITDA given the close of our transactions. And although we don't provide pro forma free cash flow for the third quarter of 2015, on a pro forma basis, adjusted EBITDA less CapEx grew by 28% in the third quarter versus the prior year.
We finished the third quarter with $60.2 billion in principal amount of debt. Our run rate annualized cash interest expense was $3.3 billion, whereas our P&L interest expense would suggest a $2.9 billion annual run rate. The P&L difference, cash, stems from the revaluation of acquired TWC debt on our GAAP balance sheet as part of purchase accounting.
As of the end of the third quarter, total net debt for the last 12 months pro forma adjusted EBITDA was 4.2x. Our long-term target leverage remains at 4 to 4.5x, and we continue to target the lower end of that range. We're deleveraging rapidly, and we continue -- and we can use that excess capacity in a number of ways. The priorities remain investment in the business, accretive M&A when available and returning capital to shareholders in the form of share repurchases.
During the third quarter, we repurchased 1.1 million in Charter shares for $281 million at an average price of about $267 per share. Share repurchase activity will continue to depend on market conditions and other potential uses of capital, and we'll be opportunistic, similar to what we did in 2011, where we provided liquidity in size and a fair price to institutional sellers. Our goal is to retain full strategic flexibility and not become trapped by formulated capital allocation guidance on buybacks.
Finally, turning to our tax assets on Slide 15. We estimate that the total value of those assets is in excess of $6 billion and is comprised of our excess basis, large NOLs and a valuable tax-sharing agreement with Advance/Newhouse. We don't currently expect to be a material cash income taxpayer until at least 2018, maybe not until 2019, and even then, our cash taxes as a percentage of GAAP pretax income, excluding the impact of higher G&A from purchase accounting, should be below statutory rates for 7 years thereafter.
Operator, we're now ready for Q&A.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions on wireless, if I could. One, just a clarification, you said that you were going to trigger the MVNO with Verizon. Has Verizon confirmed the full availability of the MVNO, the transferability from TWC to a new owner? And if so, are there any
componenttext: Two questions on wireless, if I could. One, just a clarification, you said that you were going to trigger the MVNO with Verizon. Has Verizon confirmed the full availability of the MVNO, the transferability from TWC to a new owner? And if so, are there any restrictions on the footprints that you can use it in? And then second, so you disclosed that you started buying back stock. Is there any interaction between spending that you might do on wireless and the rate at which you repurchase shares? I saw an SEC filing in which you indicated some expectation of having your own facilities in wireless.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the first question, I don't -- we've had truthful discussions with Verizon, but I don't want to characterize them beyond that. And with regard to our licenses, yes, we've asked the SEC for the right to experiment with what people call millimeter-wave t
componenttext: So the first question, I don't -- we've had truthful discussions with Verizon, but I don't want to characterize them beyond that. And with regard to our licenses, yes, we've asked the SEC for the right to experiment with what people call millimeter-wave technologies in several markets, so that we can learn how to use those products to our advantage competitively.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, Craig, at this point, from a cash flow perspective, whether you think about the MVNO or some advanced testing, this is not in the stage where it is material at all to cash flow. And so again, we're not going to trap ourselves with buyback guidanc
componenttext: I think, Craig, at this point, from a cash flow perspective, whether you think about the MVNO or some advanced testing, this is not in the stage where it is material at all to cash flow. And so again, we're not going to trap ourselves with buyback guidance, so we're always going to look for ways to reinvest in the business or apply it to more accretive M&A to the extent that exists. But that hasn't factored into our thinking right now as a significant source of capital yet in the short term.

componenttext: It didn't happen at Charter, and we went through the exact same process. And it meant that maybe the ARPU lift for customer relationship wasn't as high as it could have been if we were banging on rates, but our growth took off. And I think people are focusing on the wrong thing of trying to focus on ARPU as opposed to talking about customer relationship growth. And that's the real value with the growth strategy over time as opposed to how much rate can you take.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: {newP}A follow-up first and then a question. Chris, I know you don't want to get trapped into talking on -- guiding on the buyback, but you talked about providing liquidity to the market in the past, whereas this time, you were buying in what was a fair
componenttext:
{newP}
A follow-up first and then a question. Chris, I know you don't want to get trapped into talking on -- guiding on the buyback, but you talked about providing liquidity to the market in the past, whereas this time, you were buying in what was a fairly high period of demand at relatively high prices. How do you think about the buyback in terms of being opportunistic? And how do the Board come up with the $750 million over a 6-month period?

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't know if I should be getting into our board's thinking, but that was the number that we got, and obviously, management like as much flexibility as we could have. And the opportunistic part means in 2011, there were periods of disruption where
componenttext: Well, I don't know if I should be getting into our board's thinking, but that was the number that we got, and obviously, management like as much flexibility as we could have. And the opportunistic part means in 2011, there were periods of disruption where institutional investors approached us, and we're able to provide them liquidity. There's all the other traditional ways of going back and buying back stock, whether there's high market demand, low market demand. At the end of the day, it's just a view on what you think the growth profile of the company is and where the stock will be several years out as opposed to the next few months. If you have views on what you think the stock is worth over a multiyear period, does it look attractive, and we thought it did, and we executed on some buybacks under that authority.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And second, CapEx this quarter is fairly low. I think it -- you're delaying the -- you talked about delaying the all-digital migration. Should we expect that to be up a little bit in 4Q as you get ready for more digital conversions? And then if you
componenttext: Okay. And second, CapEx this quarter is fairly low. I think it -- you're delaying the -- you talked about delaying the all-digital migration. Should we expect that to be up a little bit in 4Q as you get ready for more digital conversions? And then if you can give us any kind of preview on '17, where it might be versus the $6.9 billion that was outlined in the proxy.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The proxy was based on a business plan of nearly 2 years ago, so I don't even -- frankly, I don't even remember what the number was. There's nothing that's changed in our thoughts about the trajectory of CapEx over time, but we closed 6 months later.
componenttext: Yes. The proxy was based on a business plan of nearly 2 years ago, so I don't even -- frankly, I don't even remember what the number was. There's nothing that's changed in our thoughts about the trajectory of CapEx over time, but we closed 6 months later. And if we see opportunities pull investment in faster, we will. So I don't want to be tethered to what we were laying out then. The trajectory is the same. And for 2017, I don't even know how much we're doing in terms of all-digital in 2017 versus 2018. That's going to be one of the large drivers, so we're not going to get into the mode of being trapped by that CapEx guidance either. But we expect the capital intensity to decline over time once we get through the all-digital.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We haven't actually done our budget yet. So we don't know what we're going to spend in 2017.
componenttext: Yes. We haven't actually done our budget yet. So we don't know what we're going to spend in 2017.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Ben Swinburne from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Ben Swinburne from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chris, just going back to the synergy and investments and sort of maybe you could help us think about the cadence. On the programming cost side, did you guys -- are you basically recognizing or have you already gotten all of the benefits from rolling to T
componenttext: Chris, just going back to the synergy and investments and sort of maybe you could help us think about the cadence. On the programming cost side, did you guys -- are you basically recognizing or have you already gotten all of the benefits from rolling to Time Warner Cable's rate card? You talked about fourth quarter being a little more of a normalized number. Maybe you could just give us some color as to why. And on the other side of it, your slide, can't remember the number, that shows insourcing, it looks like the insourcing has started. I don't know if you can give us a sense, even qualitatively as to how far along you are in terms of hiring those 20,000 people or if that's the most that's still ahead of us. And then I had a follow-up for Tom.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So look, we're intentionally not getting into it line by line as it relates to the synergy targets or what's been realized because, frankly, from an investor perspective, I don't know that it matters that much. There's one thing to talk about, the on
componenttext: Yes. So look, we're intentionally not getting into it line by line as it relates to the synergy targets or what's been realized because, frankly, from an investor perspective, I don't know that it matters that much. There's one thing to talk about, the one-time synergy; another thing is to talk about the growth curve and programming costs once you have that synergy over a multiyear period. Those are really distinct items. So for all the obvious reasons, we're not going to go line by line. I think the key thing for investors to understand is that we started off, I think, when we announced the transaction thinking it would be around $400 million in the first year -- at the end of the first year annualized. When we financed, it was at $500 million. Last quarter, it was at $600 million. This quarter, we're confirming that it's $700 million at the end of year 1 run rate, and that we're going to significantly exceed the $800 million original target for the run rate at the end of 3 years. So that's what really matters, and that's what different from Charter is going to help us fund a lot of the investments that we're doing and have a slightly different net growth curve financially for the new company. And from a programming expense line perspective, I guess the only thing I would tell you is, one, even though you step into a rate curve that has nothing to do -- that doesn't give you any indication of what slope was and the growth rate could have continued to be high on the rate card you stepped into. But we're not occurring against the contractual rate card, which we're doing. Beyond that, I'll just leave it at that. And for all the obvious reasons, we're not going to go much deeper into the topic.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And any color on how many of those heads have been brought in already that we're seeing in the P&L or?
componenttext: Okay. And any color on how many of those heads have been brought in already that we're seeing in the P&L or?

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think this is more about changing the activity and rerouting along the way. When we talk publicly about the fact that we're already building call centers, and we were doing that rapidly. So that process has started, but it's very early on, which is
componenttext: No. I think this is more about changing the activity and rerouting along the way. When we talk publicly about the fact that we're already building call centers, and we were doing that rapidly. So that process has started, but it's very early on, which is the intent of that very light shading on the -- I don't remember what page it is in the presentation, but we did give a page that is designed to show the progression of all the different operating initiatives as we see it today.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, got it. And then just Tom, just going back to your comments on enterprise, we hear that a lot from a lot of the cable operators, and it's obviously a big opportunity but also one that I don't think we've seen any one really cracked the code on yet. D
componenttext: Yes, got it. And then just Tom, just going back to your comments on enterprise, we hear that a lot from a lot of the cable operators, and it's obviously a big opportunity but also one that I don't think we've seen any one really cracked the code on yet. Do you believe you can build all the expertise in product offering, sales force, et cetera, to go after enterprise meaningfully? Or do you think you need to buy assets, either network assets or expertise, to really capture that when you look at it what seems to be, I think you said, $20 billion opportunity or footprint?

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I do think we can build it, and I think that we can change the definition of the product set that works from that marketplace as well, coming at it from a nonincumbent perspective. But one of the advantages of the new company and the new footprint is the
componenttext: I do think we can build it, and I think that we can change the definition of the product set that works from that marketplace as well, coming at it from a nonincumbent perspective. But one of the advantages of the new company and the new footprint is the regionality that has been picked up in terms of our asset base. Previously, Charter was less of a percentage of DMA in most markets that we operated in. And as a result of that, we had marketing inefficiencies. We couldn't use mass media in a lot of places. And the same effect actually impedes enterprise growth because of the regional nature of a lot of enterprises and the multi-site facilities that larger enterprises have and the inability to serve those consistently when you have a spindly footprint. And so the improvement in the footprint actually improves the opportunity that the enterprise market presents to us as well as the fact that it's -- I mean, the big news is, we have great technologies. We have the ability to put those technologies everywhere we operate, and we're really underpenetrated. And to me, that's lots of upside.

headline: Charter Communications, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
